Combo: Harvest + Owen Lars & Beru Lars + Tatooine: Lars' Moisture Farm

Lore: After pursuit, asteroids, a slug, Jedi training, capture, torture, escape, a duel, losing Han and losing a hand, Luke and Leia finally made it to the Alliance's rendezvous point.
Gametext: Deploy on one of the following systems: Rendezvous Point, Hoth, Yavin 4, Alderaan, or Sullust. Your starships deploy -2 and your pilots deploy -1 here. When battling here, you may add one battle destiny. Effect canceled if opponent controls this system. (Immune to Alter.)
IsPulled: (only to Hoth)\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once\par Wokling (V)\par Yavin 4 (V)
Combo: Haven + Echo Base Operations\par Force the Dark Side fleet into a confrontation.\par -----\par Haven + Rebel Planners + General Dodonna\par A huge and inexpensive power total at the home system.

CardName: He Can Go About His Business
Lore: "You can go about your business."
Gametext: Plays on table. Cancels Responsibility Of Command and You Overestimate Their Chances. While Brangus Glee on table, once per turn you may search opponent's Lost Pile and place all docking bays found there out of play.
Cancels: Responsibility Of Command\par You Overestimate Their Chances

Lore: "Princess Leia is wondering about Master Luke... She doesn't know where he is." "I don't know where he is." "Nobody knows where he is."
Gametext: During your control phase, target any character alone at your exterior planet sites (except a docking bay). Draw destiny. Target is missing if destiny +3 > ability.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-8)\par This Interrupt targets one of "your" exterior planet sites, and thus may play at a site only if you deployed that site card.

Lore: "All his life has he looked away. To the future, to the horizon. Never his mind on where he was! Hmm? What he was doing! Hm."
Gametext: Deploy on opponent's character. Subtracts 2 from that character's training destiny draws. OR Deploy on an opponent's pilot at a site. During each of opponent's move phases, opponent must choose to move that character, lose that character or lose 1 Force.
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-8)\par The second function of this card cannot be used to target a permanent pilot.

Lore: Once Skywalker had taken the bait, Han was of no use to the Empire.
Gametext: USED: Cancel Captive Pursuit. LOST: During your move phase, transfer an escorted captive to another bounty hunter or warrior present.
Cancels: Captive Pursuit

Lore: "And see if you can get a few of those TIE fighters to follow you."
Gametext: If your piloted unique (*) starfighter is present with opponent's piloted starfighter during your move phase at a non-cloud sector, relocate both to related system. OR Target your starfighter in battle. During this battle, your other starships may not be targeted by weapons.

Lore: At the Battle of Endor, Rebel starships fought to defend key capital starships, such as the \ul Redemption\ul0.
Gametext: USED: Add 1 to your battle destiny just drawn. STARTING: Deploy up to three Effects if each of them deploys for free, is always immune to Alter and has "deploy on table" (or "deploy on your side of table") in its game text. Place Interrupt in Lost Pile.
Information: Please check Sonn's list here:\par http://www.swccgpc.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=6432\par \par Startable Effects are:\par \par A Tragedy Has Occurred\par Aim High\par Another Pathetic Lifeform\par Battle Plan\par Battle Plan & Draw Their Fire\par Beldon's Eye (V)\par Chasm\par Civil Disorder (V)\par Colo Claw Fish\par Do, Or Do Not\par Do, Or Do Not & Wise Advice\par Don't Do That Again\par Down With The Emperor! (V)\par Evacuation Control (V)\par Ewok Celebration\par For Luck (V)\par Get To Your Ships!\par Great Shot, Kid!\par I Must Be Allowed To Speak (V)\par Insurrection\par Insurrection & Aim High\par K'lor'slug (V)\par Keeping The Empire Out Forever\par Lando's Not A System, He's A Man\par Let's Keep A Little Optimism Here\par Maneuvering Flaps (V)\par Menace Fades\par Opee Sea Killer\par Ounee Ta\par Sai'torr Kal Fas (V)\par Sando Aqua Monster\par Security Control\par Seeking An Audience (V)\par Squadron Assignments\par Staging Areas\par Steady, Steady\par Strike Planning\par Strikeforce (V)\par Superficial Damage\par The Camp\par The Shield Is Down!\par The Way Of Things\par Twilight Is Upon Me\par We Didn't Hit It\par Weather Vane\par Wokling (V)\par You've Got A Lot Of Guts Coming Here\par Your Insight Serves You Well\par Your Insight Serves You Well & Staging Areas
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-8)\par See Prepared Defenses.\par \par (AR 1.7.1, B-12)\par Prepared Defenses\par Effects that are "always immune to Alter" means any Effect which is unconditionally immune to Alter according to it's own game text, as these conditions must be met before such an Effect is on table. Therefore cards that are immune to Alter based on a condition in their game text (such as Come Here You Big Coward) cannot be deployed with this starting interrupt. Cards which are immune to Alter in their game text but can have that immunity canceled by other cards may be deployed using this Interrupt. For example, Prepared Defenses could still be used to deploy Mobilization Points even if Don't Do That Again was on table. When deploying Effects using this Starting Interrupt, each Effect deploys separately, and all automatic actions resolve normally. Thus if this starting interrupt is used to deploy Naboo Occupation, No Escape, and Imperial Arrest Order, Naboo Occupation may be deployed first (and will be immediately lost), followed by No Escape (which allows the dark side player to take the top card of the lost pile into hand) followed by Imperial Arrest Order.

Lore: Smuggler and Rebel starships use black market armor plating and deflector shields to withstand enemy fire. Expensive but life-saving modifications.
Gametext: If opponent just targeted your starship with a starship weapon, subtract 2 from each of that weapon's destiny draws.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-8)\par (Errata) When targeting a weapon that may fire repeatedly, this Interrupt reduces all of that weapon's destiny draws during the same battle, attack or whenever the weapon was fired.

Lore: The Cloud City chasm's central fin was engineered with a tensile strength unsurpassed by anything in the region, save the silk of the Kashyyyk treeworm.
Gametext: During your deploy phase, use X Force to rearrange all Cloud City sites, where X = total number of those sites. All cards at a given site move along with that site. OR Cancel Off The Edge. OR Search your Reserve Deck, take one Weather Vane into hand and reshuffle.
Pulls: Weather Vane
IsPulled: Captain Bewil
Cancels: Off The Edge

Lore: "Heavy fire, boss! Twenty-three degrees."
Gametext: If a battle was just initiated, deploy (for free) a vehicle weapon or starship weapon from hand (or Reserve Deck; reshuffle) on your participating vehicle or starship.
Pulls: A vehicle or starship weapon for free during battle.

Lore: The ultimate in armor penetration. Relies on dense capacitor banks for massive firing charge. Capacitors regularly malfunction. Hitting maneuverable targets nearly impossible.
Gametext: Use 4 Force to deploy on your Star Destroyer (adds 2 to power) or any mobile system. May target a starship using 2 Force. Draw two destiny. Subtract 1 when targeting a capital starship. Otherwise, subtract 6. Target hit if total destiny > defense value.
Information: Heavy Turbolaser Batteries deploy and fire free on Thunderflare.
IsPulled: I Can't Shake Him!

Lore: Built to penetrate the armor of the toughest Star Destroyers. Cooling technology pilfered from the Empire.
Gametext: Use 4 Force to deploy on your Star Cruiser (or Star Destroyer). Adds 2 to power. May target a starship using 2 Force. Draw two destiny. Subtract 1 when targeting a capital starship. Otherwise, subtract 6. Target hit if total destiny > defense value.
Information: Deploys free on Nebulon-B Frigate.
IsPulled: Lieutenant s'Too Vees (when at a docking bay)\par Portable Scanner\par Rapid Fire

Lore: Leia sent a \b hologram\b0  plea, "General Kenobi, years ago you served my father in the Clone Wars. Now he begs you to help him in his struggle against the Empire."
Gametext: If Obi-Wan is at a site you control, he may apply any amount of his ability toward drawing a battle destiny at any other location. Ability he uses this way cannot be used again this turn. OR One Rebel may move as a 'react' to an adjacent battle site.
Information: BG-J38 adds 2 to the destiny of each of your holograms and dejariks drawn for battle destiny or weapon destiny.
IsPulled: Holoprojector

Lore: Male \b scout\b0  from Cona. As with many Arconas, Hem has succumbed to the power of salt, an addiction indicated by his gold eye color.
Gametext: Once during each of your deploy phases, you may place, face down, one card from your hand or Force Pile under Hem, as "salt consumption." If Hem lost, cards underneath also lost. * Power = 1 + number of cards underneath.

Lore: Female Jawa shaman. Advised Wittin during his plotting with Jabba. Agreed to fan the Hutt in return for his cooperation to help usurp Kalit.
Gametext: Deploys only on Tatooine. During your control phase may search Reserve Deck, take one Utinni! or Jawa into hand and reshuffle. If you have 3 or more Jawas on table, may play Utinni! to cancel a Force drain at a related site or to cancel Control.
Pulls: Any Jawa\par Utinni!\par Daroe\par Dathcha\par Herat\par Iasa, The Traitor Of Jawa Canyon\par Jawa\par Jawa (EP1)\par Nebit\par Wittin

Lore: C-3PO had been through enough battles that many of the Rebels in the strike team considered him a good luck charm. That isn't what Han considers him.
Gametext: If a battle that opponent initiated just ended, initiate a new battle at same location. 'Reacts' are allowed only for opponent, but cards may not 'react' away or hide from battle. Loser ignores battle damage. If your droid present there, add one battle destiny (two if C-3PO).
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-8)\par See the Dark Side counterpart, Counterattack.\par \par (AR 1.7.1, B-5)\par Counterattack\par This card explicitly allows characters, vehicles and starships at the targeted location to battle again this turn (and since this is a battle, they may fire any applicable weapons). It does not allow any characters, vehicles or starships to 'react' a second time this turn. When determining the order of actions for this second battle, treat it as though it were the turn of the player who played this Interrupt. If a card was excluded from the previous battle, it may participate in this battle unless it is still prevented from participating (e.g., was targeted by Imperial Barrier).

Lore: Baragwin assigned by Jabba to be the palace's master weaponsmith. Enemy of Pote Snitkin.
Gametext: When in a battle, you may 'react' by deploying any one non-unique blaster (for free) on Hermi from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. When present with your Advosze at a site, allows your character weapons to transfer for free there.

Lore: Left to his own devices, Artoo used his spunk and creativity to save his companions' lives time and time again.
Gametext: Deploy on one of your droids. During your deploy phase, may use 1 Force to search your Reserve Deck, take one device that deploys on a droid into hand and reshuffle. Also, you may forfeit devices deployed on this droid (forfeit value = destiny number).
Pulls: Arc Welder\par Droid Sensorscope\par Fire Extinguisher\par Hidden Compartment\par Holoprojector\par Lando's Wrist Comlink\par Luke's Backpack\par Motivator (V)\par R2 Sensor Array\par Restraining Bolt\par Retractable Arm
IsPulled: Artoo\par Artoo, Come Back At Once!\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once\par Wokling (V)

Lore: The three Rebels proved to be a deadly combination time and time again.
Gametext: If Luke, Chewie and Han are in a battle together, draw destiny and subtract that amount from opponent's attrition and total power. OR If Red 5 and \ul Falcon\ul0  are in a battle together, add one battle destiny.

Lore: The Alliance lost many fine soldiers at conflicts such as the Battle of Hoth. The Rebel High Command is aware of the cost of freedom from Imperial tyranny.
Gametext: If you just forfeited a Rebel of ability > 2 from a battle at a battleground, deploy on that location; place that Rebel out of play and retrieve 2 Force for each Heroic Sacrifice on table. Immediate Effect canceled if opponent controls this location. (Immune to Control.)
IsPulled: Don't Do That Again\par Don't Do That Again - Defensive Shield\par Don't Do That Again (V) - Defensive Shield\par Harc Seff (V)\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once

Lore: Jawa \b scout\b0. Wants to avenge deaths of relatives killed in stormtrooper assault on sandcrawler. Reegesk pilfered the powerpack from his blaster at a critical moment.
Gametext: * Deploys only on Tatooine for 2 Force from each player's Force Pile. Het is power +1 for each stormtrooper at same site, unless Reegesk is present.

Lore: Standard astromech internal cargo area measures 20 centimeters by 8 centimeters. Some models have a custom compressed-air launcher for shooting flares.
Gametext: Deploy on any R-unit droid. At start of a battle, you may 'react' by deploying one character weapon (at normal use of the Force) from Reserve Deck on a warrior present; reshuffle.
Pulls: One character weapon at start of battle.
IsPulled: Corporal Beezer\par Hero Of A Thousand Devices\par Portable Scanner

Lore: Boba Fett's Mandalorian armor was so versatile that his opponents never knew what to expect.
Gametext: If Boba Fett, or your character with Mandalorian Armor is present during the weapons phase of a battle, target one opponent's character present. Draw destiny: (0-1) no effect (2-3) target immediately captured (4-5) target hit (6+) target immediately lost.
Information: Jodo Kast and Jodo Kast (V) may be targeted by Hidden Weapons.
IsPulled: Quick Reflexes when in Lost Pile.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-8)\par Mandalorian Armor refers to the device card, because it is not a characteristic (Jodo Kast may be targeted by Hidden Weapons only because his game text allows it, not because of his lore; if his game text is canceled, he can no longer be targeted).
IsCanceledBy: Fett's Blaster Rifle (V)\par Hear Me Baby, Hold Together (V)

Lore: Rebels often exploit loopholes in Imperial procedures to gain an advantage.
Gametext: Use 2 Force to deploy on your side of table. At any time, you may declare a card type. Use your Force one by one, revealing each card used, until a card of that type is revealed (take it into hand) or Force Pile is depleted.
IsPulled: The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-8)\par This Effect does not allow you to take cards from your opponent's Force Pile, even with Beggar (because Beggar does not allow you to reveal your opponent's cards).

Lore: When a Rebel is missing, ranking members of the Alliance express a professional yet dispassionate concern. Some are not so dispassionate.
Gametext: If an opponent's character with ability > 2 has just become missing, deploy on a Rebel with ability > 2 on same planet. Rebel may not participate in battle. Immediate Effect canceled if missing character is found or lost.
IsPulled: Corporal Vandolay (V)\par Fanfare\par Fanfare - Defensive Shield\par Fanfare (V) - Defensive Shield\par I'll Take Them Myself (V)\par Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-8)\par (Errata) This Immediate Effect is canceled if the missing character is no longer missing for any reason (found, lost, captured, placed in Used Pile, placed out of play etc.).

Lore: Using his position to his advantage, Luke managed to hold off Vader's onslaught, if only for a few seconds.
Gametext: USED: During a battle at a site, instead of firing one character weapon, cause one opponent's character present to be power -4 until end of turn. LOST: During a battle at a site, use 3 Force to cancel one battle destiny just drawn.
Cancels: One battle destiny just drawn.

Lore: Biker scouts train relentlessly on their speeder bikes to ensure that their speed advantage is a potent weapon. This training includes high-velocity brawling.
Gametext: Target two non-creature vehicles with maneuver (one yours, one opponent's) present at same site. Both players draw destiny; add your vehicle's maneuver to your total. Lowest total loses vehicle. OR Your speeder bike piloted by a biker scout adds one battle destiny.

Lore: "I'm backwards! You fleabitten furball...only an overgrown mophead like you would be stupid enough--"
Gametext: Deploy on C-3PO. Eyes In The Dark, The Professor, Mantellian Savrip and Hopping Mad are immune to Alter. Once during each draw phase, unless C-3PO is present with a Wookiee, you may examine the cards in your Used Pile. (Immune to Alter.)
IsPulled: The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once\par Wokling (V)

Lore: Anakin dreamt that one day he would return to Tatooine to free the slaves. His aggression will one day be felt by the entire Republic.
Gametext: Deploy on table. Each non-battleground docking bay generates no more than one Force for either player. Opponent's aliens deploy +1 on Tatooine (or +2 if non-unique or to same Tatooine site as your Dark Jedi, or +4 if both). (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Prepared Defenses.
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Lore: Many pilots for the Rebellion learned their skills using modified T-47s and other airspeeders. Being able to weave in and out of combat has become second nature to them.
Gametext: Just after the weapons segment of a battle, you may move any or all of your starships there away. ('Hit' cards must still be lost.)

Lore: Sebulba is willing to utilize a variety of 'tactics' to maintain his lead position. Mars Guo learned this lesson the hard way.
Gametext: During your control phase, use 2 Force to target opponent's Podracer with a race total within 4 of one of your race totals. Draw destiny. If destiny > target Podracer's destiny number, opponent may not draw race destiny this turn and target Podracer is 'damaged.'
Information: Now you can use the same devious methods to win a podrace that Sebulba tried in the film. During your Control Phase, you can attempt to damage and slow down an opponent's Podracer whose race total is within 4 of your own. This means you can either try to overtake a racer who is slightly ahead of yours, or you can try to create a setback for a racer gaining on one of your own. Since race destiny is drawn during the Dark Side's Control Phase, the Dark Side player has the option of playing this card before or after race destinies are drawn, although playing Hit Racer first is wise, since you may eliminate your opponent's race destiny this turn.\par \par If you successfully damage your opponent's racer, you get the immediate benefit of causing the Light Side to skip a race destiny. But even better than that is the added game text. Until the target racer is repaired, the Light Side will have to lose 1 Force in order to use any race destiny. This will potentially cause them to gradually fall behind your racer as they make hard decisions about what race destinies to keep.\par \par This card is probably best used when you are within reach of winning the race. After all, since the Light Side will retrieve 6 Force for winning the race (and even more if they're playing with cards like I Did It!), he probably won't mind losing a couple of Force in order to use race destinies that will take him across the finish line first.\par \par Of course, your opponent will need to be playing Anakin's Podracer for this to work, since Hit Racer cannot be played on a generic podracer. But with the importance that racing is likely to have in the game, it shouldn't be surprising to see Anakin's Podracer showing up in many decks.
IsPulled: We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Lore: Piloted Gold 6 at the Battle of Yavin. Flew as Dutch's wingman during an attack on an Imperial supply outpost at Kashyyyk. Befriended by Chewbacca before leaving Yavin 4.
Gametext: Adds 2 to power of anything he pilots. When piloting Gold 6 during battle, adds one destiny to total power only. When at Kashyyyk system, adds 1 to each of your Force drains there.

Information: Good against Elis Helrot.
IsPulled: Artoo & Threepio
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-8)\par This Interrupt's first function may retarget only one of the targets of an Interrupt or Utinni Effect. For example, Elis Helrot specifies two targets: a group of characters and a destination site. Thus, you may select either a different destination of the same side of the Force as the original, or a different group of Dark Side characters together at any site (which may not include any of those originally targeted), but not both. An "appropriate" target or location is one which meets the targeting or deployment requirements of the card being retargeted or relocated. The second function of this Interrupt does not relocate Utinni Effects, Mobile Effects or Immediate Effects.

CardName: I'd Just As Soon Kiss A Wookiee
Lore: "I can arrange that. You could USE a good kiss!"
Gametext: Use 3 Force to place an opponent's just deployed character, starship, vehicle, weapon, or device in opponent's hand. On opponent's next turn, that card (or one card of same title) may deploy for free.
Information: These unique Lost Interrupts (I'd Just As Soon Kiss A Wookiee and its counterpart It Can Wait) can be quite annoying, and somewhat helpful despite their low destiny numbers. They play if the opponent just deployed a card (except Immediate Effect), using 3 Force to return it to the opponent's hand.\par The Force they spent remains used, and on the next turn they must redeploy that card (if possible) for free using the same target(s). This is a great way to delay the opponent's strategy for a turn when they try to deploy a very powerful card. That alone can be worth stocking a destiny 2 card in your deck, as it gives you an extra turn to prepare for it. These cards are also great to use in an old-fashioned manipulation deck. Following up with a Grimtaash / Monnok (Used or Lost) or Recoil In Fear / Uncertain Is The Future can get rid of the "bounced" card for much longer than a single turn! If the bounced card was a character, Scanning Crew, M'iiyoom Onith, or Oola becomes even more effective!
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-9)\par (Errata) No matter where the targeted card is being deployed from (from hand, from Reserve Deck, from Bargaining Table etc.), that card is "bounced" to its owner's hand. The card that is "bounced" has been deployed (immediately before being bounced) for any triggers or automatic actions dependent upon that event. For example, an objective may flip when the character is deployed if dependent upon controlling or occupy. Similarly, if Daughter of Skywalker is being deployed from Reserve Deck (using Mind What You Have Learned), Leia will be targeted by that objective for remainder of game, even if subsequently "bounced". See Simultaneous Deployment, Ch. 5.
IsCanceledBy: Hear Me Baby, Hold Together (V)\par Protector\par Who's Scruffy-Looking?

Gametext: Unique (*) starfighters without permanent pilots are immune to attrition < 4 (or add 2 to immunity if starfighter already has immunity). Starships without pilot characters aboard are power -2. At docking bays related to systems you occupy, your Force drains are +1. Once per turn, your starfighter just lost from a system may be relocated to a related docking bay.
Information: Try this: start Hidden Base, Squadron Assignments, Insurrection and one other (I'd go Battle Plan, Menace Fades or something defense myself). What you now have is a fairly basic Hidden Base deck, drain at the systems and the lots - of - generic - docking-bays. Your pilots get beefed (insurrection) and they match their ships.\par \par Now drop down I'll Take The Leader and watch what happens - your ships are all immune to attrition < 6 (they match), you drain for two on the ground and all your ships regenerate. Plus your opponents 'no-brainer' counters (e.g. Dreadnaught, Bossk etc...) all get the shaft.\par \par They key to this is that the deck doesn't *rely* on the AO (which can be over-ridden), it just moves up a gear into a deadlyier version of itself. This is how the Admirals Orders are best used. Try it, you'll be pleasently surprised.
IsPulled: Admiral Ackbar

Lore: Vader's \b hologram\b0  exacts loyalty from his legions.
Gametext: Deploy on a planet site. Opponent's Force drains are -1 here (-2 if Vader controls an adjacent site).
Information: Article at DeckTech, November 1st, 2005\par Top 5 Damage-Controlling V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par It's a destiny-6 card that can be pulled from your deck using Masterful Move, and can reduce Force drain damage with the only stipulation being that it must be a planet site (so no Cloud City locations). There's really no easier way to reduce damage, as it requires no commitment from the Dark Side player other than that they commit a card slot to a destiny-6 Effect. If Vader's hanging around an adjacent site, this card will obviously become even more powerful. Simple Effect that can make a huge difference in a game.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par \par Wow, talk about an obvious miss on my part- great idea for a damage controller. The LS version (Projection of a Skywalker) was played quite a bit for similar reasons. The one thing that I don't like about this card is its fixed location. If you temper a drain at a planet where there are multiple sites, your opponent can always move around it. It works best at key drain locations where the enhancers (unlike lightsabers) are fixed as well.

Lore: When Vader's forces impose the New Order upon a region, Rebel resources and lifelines are quickly eliminated.
Gametext: Deploy on table. Lost if your non-Imperial character (or starship) on table. Unless you occupy fewer locations than opponent: if you win a battle, retrieve an Imperial; and, during battle, may take an Imperial just drawn for destiny into hand to cancel and redraw that destiny. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Prepared Defenses.\par -----\par(note that the pre-reset domination also triggered for initiating battle)\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par Like Ability, Ability, Ability (V), but harder to use due to the fact that you can only play with Imperials if you use this card. In addition to offering some solid character retrieval, this card also does a decent job of causing your opponent to spread out quickly so that they can suspend the gametext of this card. The battle destiny limiting may seem like a bad idea for a battling deck, but in reality there aren't a lot of ways for all-Imperial decks to get multiple battle destiny anyway, and this way you can use characters like Lord Vader and have the immunity to attrition be worth more than if you had to worry about your opponent drawing 5 battle destiny and basically making your immunity worthless. Another reason this is a solid battling card is because if you draw battle or weapon destiny and accidentally flip a character, you can take it into hand and try again, allowing you to play with more characters than you would normally be able to get away with while still maintaining the integrity of the deck's destiny.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par Wow, great minds think alike. This is my #5 as well. I really like the versatility that this card brings to an Imperial deck and think that as stronger Imperials are created this card will see more and more play.\par Armaedes made a bunch of good points about this card above, but there were a few things I also wanted to add. First, two copies of this can be played for maximum use, which means twice as many benefits heading your way. It may be overkill in many instances, but if it is worth it, you'll never go without characters ever again. Secondly, there are some creative ways for you to use it as a cycling machine. DDM had an interesting Hunt Down that used a lone Womp Rat to constantly draw against Vader so that he could draw needed Imperials into hand. I also don't think that limited destiny draws as a bad thing- with you constantly weeding out low destiny characters your 2 destinies should be stronger than your opponent's. This is also yet another great battle winning effect that works with many of the other cards on this list.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par No argument here, and the two-copies thing is an important point I forgot to mention. I have seen this card used effectively in Hunt Down, BHBM, ISB, Ralltiir, and even some Combat Readiness (V) decks. Like Ability, Ability, Ability (V), it's good because it rewards you for battling by giving you more characters to battle with. Unlike Ability, Ability, Ability (V), it's far more deck-specific, but getting back characters is always a good thing.
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Gametext: "Dejarik Rules" in effect here. Site converted by Dejarik Hologameboard.   "Dejarik Rules" in effect here.
LightSideText: "Dejarik Rules" in effect here. Site converted by Dejarik Hologameboard.
DarkSideText: "Dejarik Rules" in effect here.
Information: Giving the Dark Side two Force icons for Force generation, and one Force icon for Force draining, this location may look average at first glance. However, if you consider the "Dejarik Rules" for a moment, you will see the true power of this location.\par \par Only dejarik and hologram cards can exist at a holosite. Since there are so few of them in the Star Wars CCG card set, you're pretty safe from being battled at the Imperial Holotable.\par \par Holosites allow dejariks and holograms to deploy and battle there as if they were characters. However, they are not characters and are not targetable as characters, interrupts or effects . . . they are dejariks and holograms! So you're completely safe from cards like Surprise Assault.\par \par When you deploy a dejarik or hologram card to a holosite, use its destiny number as its deploy, forfeit, power and ability numbers. Battles at holosites are similar to battles at other sites (including destiny draws and attrition if you have 4 or more ability present). So Visage Of The Emperor (destiny = power = ability = 7) and Image Of The Dark Lord (destiny = power = ability = 6) are extremely powerful holograms to be reckoned with at the Imperial Holotable - the Light Side doesn't have any dejariks or holograms that can compete with these cards on a one-to-one basis!\par \par I like to start with the Imperial Holotable, and pack two Visage Of The Emperor, two Image Of The Dark Lord, and two Monnok cards in my deck. This number of dejariks and holograms assures me a card that I can deploy to the Imperial Holotable on my first couple of turns, and gives me a nice, steady (and safe!) Force drain throughout the game.
IsPulled: Masterful Move\par Masterful Move & Endor Occupation

You may retrieve 1 Force whenever you deploy a matching operative to the Renegade planet. Your matching operatives on that planet are each forfeit +2 and, when at same site as a Rebel, are each power +2. When you have at least one matching operative in a battle on the Renegade planet, you may add one battle destiny. \par \b Flip\b0  this card if you do not occupy at least two battleground sites related to the Renegade planet.
Information: Article on DeckTech, August 19th, 2007 '2nd Annual SWCCG Encyclopedia of Decks' by Brandon "Jabba_the_Ruck" Ruck\par http://www.decktech.net/starwarsccg/articles/articles.php?id=6526&view=2\par \par Idea Behind Objective: A very stupid idea. At first, the original strategy was to play a deck with 25 of your planet's Operative because they were broken on their planet. Basically it worked like this; your objective pulled the sites, then once you controlled three, you flipped. The flip side made all lightside drains -1, your operatives added +1 to force drains, deployed for one, forfeit for like 4 or 5, added a destiny at all sites while you had just one operative on the planet, and you retrieved a force every time you simply deployed one to a site. They were even power +2 against a Rebel. This was totally not a Star Wars movie idea, just crap that hurt the game.\par \par SPECIAL NOTE: Because of all the problems this objective caused. Decipher created three cards that completely hurt this deck as well as an errata to the rules saying that only one operative may be at a site, anymore would be lost. This objective is considered to be DEAD. Decipher created this idea with no thought of what they were doing. This objective is one that they wish they had never made. It won the '98 worlds for both sides because it was a broken idea.\par \par What Changed Since 1st Edition: Nothing, the objective still stinks. You play it, you are doing it as a surprise factor only. The only reason you should win with this objective is against someone who isn't playing with the counter cards or who doesn't know how it works. STAY AWAY!!!
Rules: This objective may not start a <> site that may not deploy to a Renegade planet.

Lore: "Obi-Wan has taught you well."
Gametext: Cancel All Too Easy, Imperial Barrier (targeting your Jedi), Stunning Leader (where your Jedi participating), or You Are Beaten (except when canceling Uncontrollable Fury). [Immune to Sense] OR Once per game, if opponent just initiated a battle, you may take the first weapons segment action.
Information: Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par Last on the list because of how specific it is, but still a solid battling helper due to its ability to cancel just about every battle evasion method dark side can come up with. The trick is that it has to be targeting a Jedi, but frankly most light battling decks are going to be heavy on the Jedi anyway (Mace Windu (V), Qui-Gon Jinn, Obi-Wan Kenobi and possible a Jedi persona of Luke Skywalker). Cancelling battle evasion is obviously a very good thing for a battling deck, but the card doesn't stop there. If your main should survive the battle and are still at the site, and the dark player retaliates, you can use this card to take the first action of the weapons phase, which means you can strike out at one of your opponent's characters before they have a chance to do any tricks with Dr. Evazan or Dark Strike.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par #5?? Aw, man it's my #1. I don't want to steal my own thunder- so read on. I think this was a very good card to come out of the player designed card experiment.\par When you deploy to battle in modern SWCCG, the biggest thing you fear is the re-beat, where your opponent minimizes your offensive power, reinforces on their turn, and then beats you down. Evasion and character removal are two prime ways to slow down a feisty LS player. IMI takes care of it all. I don't think its specificity is a hindrance at all. Barrier will often be saved for your big guns (Jedi). Most battles involve Jedi (Stunning), and YAB will target those aforementioned big guns. Being able to battle on your own terms is very nice. The secondary text is quite nice as well, as Armaedes pointed out. Though protective in nature, it can turn a defensive battle into an offensive one quickly.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par I agree that this is a great card, but #1? This is a very deck-specific card, as it won't work in a battling deck that isn't mains, and even in a mains deck it won't help you with EPP Luke. A very nice card no doubt, as it made my own list, but not an auto-play by any means.
Combo: Impressive, Most Impressive (V) + Sorry About The Mess & Blaster Proficiency\par These two cards allow you to control the battle by eliminating one character before anything else happens.
Cancels: All Too Easy\par Imperial Barrier\par Stunning Leader\par You Are Beaten

Lore: "They'll be in range of our tractor beam in moments, my lord." "Good. Prepare the boarding party and set your weapons for stun."
Gametext: If you have a Star Destroyer in a battle, during the weapons segment use its tractor beam for free. Add 2 to tractor beam destiny if targeting a unique (*) starship. If not captured, target is power and maneuver -3 for remainder of battle.
Information: Taking out a starship early in a battle is an outstanding tactical advantage.
Combo: In Range + any Star Destroyer + Tractor Beam\par -----\par In Range + Our First Catch of the Day

Lore: Incom's core design team defected to the Alliance with the plans for the famed X-wing fighter. Once with the Alliance, many former Incom test pilots flew for the Rebellion.
Gametext: Deploy on a Rebel Base interior site. Your ability-1 permanent pilots aboard T-16s, T-47s, Z-95s and X-wings (except squadrons) are replaced by ability-2 permanent pilots who add 1 to power. Canceled if opponent controls this site. (Immune to Alter.)
IsPulled: Commander Luke Skywalker (V)\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once\par Wokling (V)

Lore: After narrowly escaping the nationalization of Incom by the Empire, many former employees joined the Rebellion. They spent long hours maintaining X-wings and T-47s.
Gametext: At same and related locations, adds 2 to your total battle destiny where your X-wing, T-47, T-16 or Z-95 is present and makes those vehicles and starships immune to attrition < 3 (< 5 if he is present with your maintenance droid).

Lore: \b Enclosed\b0  vehicle used for shuttling and hot-rodding. E-16/x ion engine pushes T-16 up to 1200 kph.
Gametext: May add 1 passenger. Permanent pilot provides ability of 1. May move as a 'react.' * Landspeed = 4. OR 1 character may shuttle to or from same site for free.

Lore: The lightsaber is an extremely versatile weapon, making a Jedi a rather difficult opponent to slow down. "This is impossible!"
Gametext: Cancel Imperial Barrier, None Shall Pass, or Set For Stun. OR Peek at the top card of your Force Pile; either return it, or place it under your Force Pile or Reserve Deck.
Cancels: Control & Set For Stun\par Imperial Barrier\par None Shall Pass\par None Shall Pass (V)\par Set For Stun

Lore: With its superior numbers, the Empire knowingly sacrifices the safety of many units and weapons in order to preserve the greater war machine.
Gametext: Deploy on table. Each turn, each of your characters, vehicles, and starships may forfeit one of its weapons (except a lightsaber) using forfeit value = 3. Also, your forfeited weapons go to Used Pile. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Prepared Defenses.
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans\par You Cannot Hide Forever\par You Cannot Hide Forever & Mobilization Points
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-9)\par The game text "may forfeit one of its weapons" means that a character, starship or vehicle may only forfeit a weapon deployed on that character, starship or vehicle. Thus a character cannot use this Effect to forfeit an artillery weapon at the same location, a starship cannot forfeit an Orbital Mine at the same system and so on. The game text that allows your forfeited weapons go to your Used Pile applies to any weapon you forfeit (including artillery weapons that already have a forfeit value).

Lore: Communications starship. Often hosts first assignment for top prospects from among newly commissioned officers.
Gametext: May add 5 pilots, 6 passengers, 1 vehicle and 3 starfighters. Has ship-docking capability. Permanent pilot provides ability of 2. Immune to attrition < 3 (< 4 if Rebel leader aboard).
Information: Admiral Ackbar (V) adds one battle destiny while piloting a Star Cruiser.

Lore: To succeed in the Imperial Navy, an officer must be willing to take risks. Difficult choices must be made.
Gametext: Deploy on any Effect or Utinni Effect (except those immune to Alter). During each of owner's draw phases, if you occupy an asteroid sector, owner must choose to either lose 1 Force or voluntarily cancel that Effect or Utinni Effect. (Immune to Alter.)

Gametext: Relocate one of your characters from a Cloud City site to Weather Vane (if 'hit', character is fi rst restored to normal). May be played even after a battle has just been initiated.

Lore: Produced by Sienar for TIE bombers and TIE defenders, using plans stolen from Slayn & Korpil by ISB agents. Often sold to bounty hunters and mercenaries by Black Sun.
Gametext: Deploy on your TIE Bomber, TIE Defender or freighter. May target a capital starship for free. Draw destiny. Add 3 if that capital starship was targeted by another weapon this turn. Target hit if total destiny > defense value. After firing, place Missile in Used Pile.
IsPulled: I Can't Shake Him!

Lore: Prototype missile developed by Slayn & Korpil. Ionizing warhead disrupts onboard systems. Capable of destroying capital starships by overloading shield generators.
Gametext: Deploy on your B-wing, Z-95, YT-1300 Transport or \ul Falcon\ul0. May target a capital starship for free. Draw destiny. Add 3 if that capital starship was targeted by another weapon this turn. Target hit if total destiny > defense value. After firing, place Missile in Used Pile.
IsPulled: Lieutenant s'Too Vees (when at a docking bay)\par Portable Scanner\par Rapid Fire
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, F-1, Appendix A)\par -----\par Changes to "Characteristics" re: "(LS) Intruder Missile"\par \par Intruder Missile may not deploy on Outrider:\par \par http://www.swccgpc.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=16525\par \par Changes to "Characteristics" and application to "(LS) Intruder Missile":\par \par In an ideal world we'd have no characteristics rules and lists and instead just list all aspects of a card, on the card. Since that would require a revision to thousands of cards, that's simply not practical. Every effort has been made to identify and discern what are and are not characteristics. Some may be missing from the list, while others are deliberately absent. Discerning which is which requires a bit of research and judgment.\par \par After investigating, we're adding skiff and sandcrawler to the list of characteristics which apply to vehicles.\par \par This brings us to the matter of (LS) Intruder Missile. This weapon and its possible interaction with Outrider has been a matter the PC has been considering for some time. By the rules, the one could not deploy on the other, but we were not ignorant of the possibility that this was an error of omission. Having looked through the evidence, we're now confident that Intruder Missile was not intended to work with Outrider.\par \par We do not make these decisions lightly, and attempt to be thorough in our research of the original intent of the card interactions. We searched the records of play testing that we have from the development of Shadows of the Empire (the set that was incorporated into Reflections 2). In an original version of the Outrider, it was created to work with Intruder Missile, both via game text and the inclusion of the "YT-2400" in the subtype box. However, the game text was stricken over the course of play testing, and the "YT-2400" text moved out of the subtype box into the lore. This move was significant - the characteristic rules were well in place at this time, and Decipher had ensured that references to starships were almost entirely to icons or the contents of the subtype box. The only exceptions to this were defined characteristics (all ships are enclosed and all TIE/sa and B-wings are bombers) or squadron designations (which could be found in title, lore, or game text). Decipher, in fact, released only one card which was referenced by its lore instead of subtype: Blockade Flagship, because "Droid Control Ship" would not fit in that box - and Decipher then made a note to declare Droid Control Ship a characteristic.\par \par Neither of these cases applied to Outrider - our tests using the original templates showed that "YT-2400" would fit with room to spare, and we know that Decipher made no such announcement. In addition, the text on Intruder Missile states that it also may deploy on the Falcon. It was not until two years after Intruder Missile came out that a Falcon was created that didn't state "YT-1300" in lore (both the original and Lando in Millennium Falcon did). If Decipher intended to reference it in lore, this specific mention wouldn't have been necessary.\par \par Given the state of the characteristic rules at the time by Decipher, the striking of the game text, and the deliberate choice to remove a referenced card aspect from the subtype box, we feel this is sufficient evidence to support the existing ruling: Intruder Missile may not deploy on Outrider.\par \par Because this matter has confused many players over the years, we are going to issue the following errata to Intruder Missile (LS) in the hopes of minimizing further confusion:\par \par LS Intruder Missile:\par Deploy on your B-wing, Z-95, YT-1300 Transport, or Falcon. May target a capital starship for free. Draw destiny. Add 3 if that capital starship was targeted by another weapon this turn. Target hit if total destiny > defense value. After firing, place Missile in Used Pile.

Lore: "Sir, might I suggest that you -- It can wait."
Gametext: Use 3 Force to place an opponent's just deployed character, starship, vehicle, weapon, or device in opponent's hand. On opponent's next turn, that card (or one card of same title) may deploy for free.

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-9)\par (Errata) See I'd Just As Soon Kiss A Wookiee.\par \par (AR 1.7.1, B-9)\par I'd Just As Soon Kiss A Wookiee\par (Errata) No matter where the targeted card is being deployed from (from hand, from Reserve Deck, from Bargaining Table etc.), that card is "bounced" to its owner's hand. The card that is "bounced" has been deployed (immediately before being bounced) for any triggers or automatic actions dependent upon that event. For example, an objective may flip when the character is deployed if dependent upon controlling or occupy. Similarly, if Daughter of Skywalker is being deployed from Reserve Deck (using Mind What You Have Learned), Leia will be targeted by that objective for remainder of game, even if subsequently "bounced". See Simultaneous Deployment, Ch. 5.

Lore: Things went from bad to worse when Luke was attacked by a dianoga, a parasitic predator native to the planet Vodran.
Gametext: If It Could Be Worse was just played, it is canceled and you may use X Force to raise damage against opponent by X amount. OR If opponent just lost Force from a battle, play to increase loss by 1 Force.
Information: Combo Card: Ommni Box & It's Worse
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-9)\par When this Interrupt increases your opponent's Force loss, this is simply a modifier; it does not create a new, separate instance of Force loss. It Could Be Worse is played during the result step of a Force loss action, and therefore the chance for optional responses to that Force loss action has already passed. For example: the Dark Side player Force drains for 2. The Light Side player has no response to the Force drain (neither does the Dark Side player) and the Force drain now has its result. The Light Side player now plays It Could Be Worse and uses 2 Force. The Dark Side player responds to It Could Be Worse by playing It's Worse and using 5 Force. Neither player has any responses to the It's Worse (the Light Side player doesn't have his Sense in hand) and thus it has its result. The Force drain loss is now 7 Force and Light Side cannot play his Control because the optional response step to the Force drain is already over.
Cancels: It Could Be Worse

Lore: Good natured, optimistic herders from Ithor. Plant trees and reforest areas. Sided with the Rebellion at great risk to their home planet.
Gametext: Power and forfeit +2 while Momaw Nadon at Audience Chamber. While at any jungle, swamp, forest or exterior Endor site, adds one (Dark Side Force icon) icon and one (Light Side Force icon) icon. Prevents (selective creature icon) creatures from attacking where present.

When this happens, you may not use any of IT-O's or the Hypo's game text that requires the presence of captives (because the Light Side cannot have captives).

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-10)\par The phrase "to move requires +2 Force" on this alien applies only when Jabba is using his own landspeed.

Lore: Jabba Desilijic Tiure. Male heir to Zorba the Hutt. \b Gangster\b0. \b Leader\b0  of one of the largest criminal organizations in the galaxy. Over six hundred years old.
Gametext: While with your alien leader, Jabba is immune to attrition and may not be targeted by Interrupts or weapons. May deploy one Scum And Villainy from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. During battle, may use 1 Force to double the power of one other non-[maintenance] alien present.
Information: Jabba personas are:\par \par Jabba\par Jabba Desilijic Tiure\par Jabba The Hutt\par Jabba The Hutt (V)\par Mighty Jabba\par -----\par The other 'alien leader' may be Ephant Mon, who is pulled by Power Of The Hutt.\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par If the power of Scum could be placed at the feet of one character, it would be this one, which is ironic since Jabba doesn't even really have feet. Jabba The Hutt (V) is very deck-specific, which is why he's not higher on my list, but in an alien deck he can end games on the 2nd or 3rd turn. I have personally had Jabba The Hutt (V) cause more than 50 overflow in games, and I know other players who have got that number even higher. With the number of ways dark side has to pull aliens from the deck, and with Jabba (V) doubling the power of almost all of them, you can create devastating beatdowns in record time. The best part is that the Audience Chamber deploys him from Reserve Deck and then Elis Helrot takes him wherever the fighting is. Truly a brutal battling card.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par Well, I might take exception on the power of Scum being focused on him, but you are right that he is a potent card. I mean, winning a battle by 20 and winning it by 40 both hurt your opponent, but both are likely game winners. I didn't rank him on my list since I don't really like what he brings to the world of SWCCG. I think there were plenty of other cool Jabbas that Scum decks could run, plus I have trouble envisioning Jabba being a flying beatdown machine.
Pulls: Scum And Villainy
Combo: Jabba The Hutt (V) + Ephant Mon + Chokk\par Efficient Combo; Ephant Mon is an alien leader.\par -----\par Bib Fortuna (EP1) is power 12 when Jabba uses 1 Force to double power.\par-----\par Jabba The Hutt (V) + 4-LOM With Concussion Rifle\par 4-LOM adds one battle destiny with Jabba.\par -----\par Jabba The Hutt (V) + Boelo\par Cancel one opponent's battle destiny.

Lore: Han Solo was frozen in carbonite to test the process Vader planned to use on Luke. When Boba Fett delivered Han to Jabba, the vile gangster called him his "favorite decoration".
Gametext: Jabba's Prize is a Dark Side card. \ul Deploys only at start of game if Carbon Chamber Testing is on table to Security Tower, frozen and imprisoned, (instead of a Rebel from opponent's Reserve Deck). If You Can Either Profit By This . . . is on table, opponent does not deploy Han at start of game (relocate Jabba's Prize to Audience Chamber, flip Carbon Chamber Testing, and you may not move or transfer Jabba's Prize)\ul0. May not be placed in Reserve Deck. Jabba's Prize is a persona of Han only while on table. If Jabba's Prize leaves table, place it out of play. May not be targeted by We're The Bait or Someone Who Loves You. While Jabba's Prize is at Audience Chamber, Jabba is power +3, defense value +3, and adds 3 to his immunity to attrition. If Jabba's Prize was just released, opponent may replace it with any Han from hand, Used Pile, or Reserve Deck; reshuffle (if not replaced, place Jabba's Prize out of play).
Combo: Jabba's Prize + Carbon Chamber Testing Objective + Despair (V)
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-10)\par Since this character is only ever on table as a captive, all the character's game text is considered applicable to his status as a captive (in other words, all his game text is applied whenever appropriate).

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-10)\par Unless you are deploying to your own Jawa Camp, when you deploy a non-unique Jawa you must use 1 Force and your opponent must use 1 Force (each player uses 2 or more Force when Dathcha or Het Nkik is deployed). Information: If you have a deck which is designed around setting up big beatdowns (eg. with Jedi Presence and supporting cards like Courage of a Skywalker), Treva is your most effective way of stopping your opponent using Ghhhk to avoid the battle damage when combined with Draw Their Fire. The other methods of achieving this result - Frozen Assets and Beggar - are each canceled by the Fanfare shield, so Treva is probably the best way to abuse Draw Their Fire in this way. (Psychobabble)

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-10)\par (Errata) The Jedi targeted does not have to be a Rebel.

Lore: \b Dejarik\b0  of venomous swamp creature from Noe'ha'on. Keen senses of smell and vision. Dangerous hunter. Lays eggs - hundreds of ravenously hungry hatchlings.
Gametext: Deploy on table. If your character, starship, or vehicle in battle is about to be lost (or crashed) before the damage segment, it is instead lost at end of battle (if forfeited, forfeit for 0). [Immune to Alter].
Information: Startable with Heading For The Medical Frigate.\par -----\par BG-J38 adds 2 to the destiny of each of your holograms and dejariks drawn for battle destiny or weapon destiny.\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par One of my pet peeves, briefly touched upon under #1, is character removal. The Dark Side is rife with popular ways to get rid of your heroes such as Dr. Evazan, Dark Strike, and Choke Vader. K'lor Slug (and Molator for the DS) helps you avoid painful beatdowns due to sudden losses of power and destiny draws. While this is more like IMI in that it helps your battles hold their effectiveness, the second part of the text goes very well with immunity mains. Your mains can get out at their normal cost, which greatly speeds up the time it takes to get them into play by a turn or more.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par Again, I find this less of an offensive aid than a defensive aid, and more of a battle-hindering card than anything else. The dark side's character removal is a big way dark wins battles, so in my opinion taking this away makes effective battling more challenging. I really like this card - I think it is a necessary component of the game - but I'm not sure I would classify it as a battling aid.
IsPulled: Escape Pod (V)\par Holoprojector\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once\par Don't Tread On Me (V)

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-10)\par The deployment benefit from this system location affects each applicable character, not each characteristic. Thus, a Wookiee who is also a smuggler (e.g. Chewbacca) is deploy -2 here, not deploy -4.

Lore: Hunters who track down escaped Wookiee slaves and report on their location. The Empire and Trandoshans pay a high price for that kind of information.
Gametext: While at a Kashyyyk site, adds 1 to your Force drains there, is power +1 (or +2 if your Trandoshan is on Kashyyyk) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Kashyyyk from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.
Pulls: One site to Kashyyyk.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, D-2)\par Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex). \par Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows: \par - You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title. \par - If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost). \par - Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.

Gametext: Deploy on Kessel. Target one of your smugglers at another system. X = parsec distance between the two systems. When target reaches Kessel, opponent draws destiny. If = 0, starship lost. Otherwise, by returning to first system, 'retrieve' X Lost Force. Lose Utinni Effect.

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-10)\par This Utinni Effect must be deployed upon the Kessel system location. This Utinni Effect defines X at the time the smuggler is targeted, and X remains the same even if the parsec distance between the two systems subsequently changes. If moving your smuggler from Kessel to complete the Kessel Run also returns control of the Kessel system (Dark side location) to Dark Side (thus the Dark Side location game text comes into effect) then the completion of the Kessel Run and the canceling of the Kessel Run are two automatic actions triggered at the same time, and are resolved as such.

Lore: Couriers. Watchful for any kind of activity by the Alliance or the Empire. Sell their information to anyone willing to buy.
Gametext: While at a Kiffex site: adds 1 to your Force drains there, is power +1 (or +2 if your spy is on Kiffex) and, once during each of your deploy phases, may deploy one site to Kiffex from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.
Pulls: One site to Kiffex.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, D-2)\par Operatives are identified by their title, X Operative, with X being a system. The operative is considered a 'matching operative' for system X (e.g., Kiffex Operative is a matching operative for Kiffex). \par Operatives are restricted by special rules as follows: \par - You may not voluntarily deploy or move your operative to (or through) a location on its matching planet where you already have an operative (even if inactive) of the same card title. \par - If, at any time, two of your Operatives (even if inactive) of the same card title are at the same location on their matching planet, you must choose one to be lost (you may choose an inactive operative to be lost). \par - Your operative character on its matching planet may not apply its ability toward drawing battle destiny. Your operative may not control a location on its matching planet for any reason unless you have other cards there capable of controlling the location (e.g., an ability-1 character or a battle droid). Your operatives still occupy that location (and may battle or be battled), but may not Force drain or flip an objective alone.

Lore: Dobreed used to have dreams of opening up his own shop in Mos Espa. Now broke from his gambling activities, he provides transportation services to pay for his urges.
Gametext: During your move phase, target any or all of your characters at one exterior site to 'transport' (relocate) to another exterior site. Draw destiny. Use that much Force to 'transport,' or place Interrupt in Lost Pile.
Information: Elis Helrot has same function, it is not limited to players move phase and relocates from any site to any site.\par Advantage of Lana Dobreed is that there are no counters to it.
IsPulled: Rayno Vaca
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-10)\par See Elis Helrot.\par \par (AR 1.7.1, B-6)\par Elis Helrot\par (Errata) The following actions are part of the initiation of this Interrupt:\par - targeting the characters to be moved;\par - targeting the site to move them to;\par - drawing destiny; and\par - paying the cost (using the Force required to transport the targeted characters).

Lore: Special modification for starfighters. Size may vary depending on mass of starship. Allows a stable connection to a spacedock, uneven terrain or even another starship.
Gametext: Deploy on your starfighter. During any control phase, may target one opponent's capital starship present. Starfighter attaches to target (automatically moves with target and is 'concealed'). May detach at any time (even as target begins to move).
Information: This device permits you to create an "Undercover" starfighter. You block your opponent's Force drain without risking loosing Force in a battle.\par \par Of course, since you can only have two on the table at a time, you will still have to deploy other ships and attack, but now you have an ace in the hole. Not only do the ships present at the system engage the Imperial fleet, but your concealed starfighter "May detach at any time", thus increasing your power and ability total to give your opponent a run for his money.
IsPulled: Corporal Beezer\par Portable Scanner
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-10)\par This device allows your starfighter to attach itself to an opponent's capital starship. To indicate that your starfighter is attached, place it across the table on the targeted capital starship card. While 'concealed':\par - Starship is inactive, thus all cards aboard it are inactive (except for cards that indicate they still function, such as Homing Beacon and Landing Claw itself).\par - Your opponent may not Force drain at same location. When you 'detach,' the starfighter returns to normal. While attached, if the capital starship is lost, the attached starfighter is also lost. A starfighter attached to a starship that lands is still considered attached. If detached (or if the Landing Claw is canceled) the starfighter becomes landed at that location (if this is not possible, then starfighter is lost).\par \par (Appendix B)\par While attached, if the capital starship is lost, the attached starfighter is also lost. The capital starship is considered to be 'carrying' the attached starfighter, so if the capital starship moves away, and the attached starfighter comes along for the ride, that starfighter is being 'carried,' not moving on its own. See Movement - carrying cards.
IsCanceledBy: Captain Godherdt\par Ghhhk & Those Rebels Won't Escape Us\par Homing Beacon\par Those Rebels Won't Escape Us

Gametext: Deploy on table. Once per turn, may target a character present with [Cloud City] Lando. For remainder of turn, target is forfeit = 0. During battle on Cloud City, you may use X Force (maximum 3) to add X to your total battle destiny. (Immune to Alter.)

Lore: Easily concealed device used by Lando to remain in contact with his subordinates. Directly connected to Cloud City's central computer.

Characteristics: cannon, laser cannon, laser cannon battery
Lore: Trade Federation battleships use concealed quad laser emplacements. Though their coverage is limited, the surprise factor and ferocious firing rate is often overwhelming.
Gametext: Deploy on your capital starship. May deploy as a 'react'. May target a starship using X Force, where X = 0 to 3. Draw destiny. Subtract 2 if targeting a starship with maneuver. If destiny +X > defense value, target hit and opponent loses 1 Force.
Information: May deploy aboard TIE Defender Mark I.

Lore: Security corridors are guarded by a grid of laser emplacements which can be activated upon demand to seal off sensitive areas from intrusion.

Lore: Laser system activated by distress signal from guards. Used at security checkpoints and detention block control rooms. Targeting guided by centralized droid controller.
Gametext: Use 2 Force to deploy on an interior sire. May target a seeker (use defense value = 1), character or creature for free. Draw destiny. Target hit if destiny -1 > defense value. Laser Projector may be targeted by any weapon (use defense value = 1).

Lore: Starships can become damaged in combat and rendered ineffective until they can be repaired and re-outfitted.
Gametext: Deploy on any system. Target an opponent's starship. Target's power and forfeit = 0. When target reaches Utinni Effect, target draws one destiny. Utinni Effect canceled if destiny > 2. Otherwise, draw again next move phase, etc.
Information: Lateral Damage is lost when the target is lost.\par -----\par Playing lateral damage on, say, your DSII when your opponent doesn't satisfy Come Here You Big Coward or occupy another battleground system is fun. They move over to cancel it and then they have to pay for their ground drain and can't drain you in space - annoying.\par (Psychobabble)

Lore: Adopted daughter of the Viceroy and First Chairman of Alderaan. Became a political \b leader\b0  at a young age. The injustices of the New Order led her to join the Rebellion.
Gametext: While at opponent's Senate, Leia's game text may not be canceled and may lose 1 Force to place Leia and any character present out of play. During battle, may cancel game text of a leader of ability < 5 with Leia for remainder of turn.
Information: Leia Organa personas are:\par \par Boushh\par Daughter Of Skywalker\par Daughter Of Skywalker (V)\par General Leia Organa\par Leia\par Leia (V)\par Leia Organa\par Leia Organa (V)\par Leia With Blaster Rifle\par Leia, Rebel Princess\par Princess Leia\par Princess Leia (V)\par Princess Leia Organa\par Princess Organa\par Prisoner 2187\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par Leia is a revolutionary card. She is a very cheap destiny draw that allows for an early disruption of the Dark Side's setup. Though envisioned as an anti-Senate card, she has many other strong uses. Most used is probably her leader canceling game text, which can set up some beats of her own. She can take the teeth out of Jabba, Xizor, P-59, Fel, Igar, Ephant Mon, Veers, Thrawn, and Tarkin. This text always works as well. Typically, such a powerful card wouldn't be so cheap, but she has been an early thorn in my opponent's side for some time now. Usually my choice for a utility Leia, but Princess Leia (V) deserves consideration as well.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par YES! Leia (V) is a fantastic battling card. Not only does she have strong gametext for battling herself, but she also takes a bite out of senate, which is a deck that makes effective battling by the light side more challenging. I would even put this Leia above EPP Leia for battling effectiveness. Great pick by Shewski!
IsPulled: I Know\par Leia's Back\par Yavin 4: Massassi War Room (V)

Thus you may fire repeatedly first shot free, subsequent shots at 2 Force, At the same target at +3 to your weapon destiny draw, and the hit characters are forfeit - 3. Take out the the "r" and the "n" and your closer to his true capabilities in an Endor Booster Draft.\par \par For one, he's a scout. Thus Pitiful Little Band can be used with him. He's power 2 and ability 2 for only 2 Force, and with Imperial Arrest Order on table he's forfeit 5!\par \par But there's more! He can drive a Speeder Bike, as well as fly a starship. Lore: Former warrant officer from Concord Dawn. Promoted due to superb performance. Specializes in transporting high-profile criminals. Twin brother of a famous mercenary.
Gametext: During your control phase, may use 1 Force to search your Reserve Deck, take one Human Shield into hand and reshuffle. When escorting a captive, captive is forfeit +2 and Sheckil is immune to attrition < 4.
Information: You've captured a group of Rebels and are escorting them to the Cloud City: Security Tower to do mean and nasty things to them. (OK, most of those things involve Force losses and torture with creepy devices, but still, that's pretty mean!) Heading down the Cloud City: Upper Plaza Corridor you're just about there, when suddenly the Light Side sets up an ambush. Things are looking bad as the Light Side wins a spectacular battle, but they overlooked one thing. You've got Lieutenant Sheckil. You play the interrupt Human Shield using its lost game text. Now any captive present may be forfeited to meet the attrition and battle loss. Lieutenant Sheckil adds 2 to any captive he is escorting, so you can easily meet the battle loss and attrition. Guess it wasn't such a good idea to attack!\par \par Lieutenant Sheckil is an expert at escorting captives. He's also an expert at protecting the Dark Side from harm by using captives as shields. During your control phase, you may use 1 Force to take one Human Shield into hand from the Reserve Deck. Sheckil also adds 2 to the forfeit value of any captive he escorts. To take full advantage of him, you absolutely need the card Human Shield. This card in a Used form allows you to use captives as target fodder for your opponent's weapons. As a Lost Interrupt, you can use those captives he's escorting to meet battle damage and attrition, thus saving your own forces.
Pulls: Human Shield
IsPulled: Blizzard 4
Combo: Lieutenant Sheckil + Human Shield + Binders
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, A-11)\par The name "Sumner" in this card's game text is a misprint and should read "Sheckil".

Information: Have you ever looked at Zuckuss In Mist Hunter and wanted to sic that same torture on the Dark Side, just to see how they'd feel? Well, here's your chance! Lieutenant Williams on the Radiant VII gives you a very similar ability: if your opponent has total ability less than seven piloting at Williams's system, his total battle destiny is -3. Not quite as good as Zuckuss, but then again, Zuckuss doesn't have 7 power and immunity to attrition < 5.\par \par Since Williams's ability only works while the Radiant VII is alone at a system, you'll want to supplement him with two other pilots to maximize the Radiant's power in space. But even if you don't find yourself in the need for space support, Williams works well as forfeit fodder on the ground, with reasonable stats to supplement your main characters in their quest for ground-poundin' dominance. And, since he's a Republic character, he's immune to annoying things like Scanning Crew.
Combo: Lieutenant Williams + Captain Madakor + Radiant VII
Matching: Obi-Wan In Radiant VII\par Radiant VII

Lore: Vader had to show Luke that giving in to the dark side of the Force was his only destiny.
Gametext: USED: If a battle was just initiated where you have a character armed with a lightsaber, characters may not be targeted by lightsabers for remainder of battle. LOST: If opponent just initiated a duel, opponent must choose to lose 4 Force or cancel the duel.
Information: The Lost game text on this Used or Lost Interrupt is, well, a little lost on us for the moment. A dueling version of Projective Telepathy, this card makes the Light Side choose to either lose 4 Force or cancel a duel they just initiated. At the moment, there are only two ways for the Light Side to initiate a duel. The first is through Jedi Test #6, a strategy not seen very often. The second (and more likely to be seen) is the Interrupt from Tatooine, You'll Find I'm Full Of Surprises, which gives Luke some dueling ability. Lightsaber Parry will be useful against this card, as well as any future duel-initiating ability the Light Side might gain in the future.\par \par Lightsaber Parry also provides some interesting Used game text. If the Dark Side has a lightsaber in a just-initiated battle, this card will eliminate the ability of all lightsabers present to target characters. At first glance, this might seem a little silly. After all, while the Light Side won't be slicing and dicing, the Dark Side can't use their lightsabers, either. But there is a method to the madness. The Light Side still outnumbers the Dark in number of characters who can use the various unique lightsabers. In addition, the Light Side has a little more versatility, with Anakin's Lightsaber being usable by either Luke or Leia. These facts add up to a decent chance that the Light Side will have more lightsabers in a battle than the Dark Side. Now, sacrificing Darth Maul's chance to hit an opponent is more than offset by the fact that you have saved several of your characters from the blade.\par \par This text can also be useful when you have an important character with a low defense value in the battle. Characters with 1, 2, or even 3 ability are almost sure to be hit by a lightsaber. Now your Dark Jedi can keep that character alive and kicking for at least another turn. And since this part of Lightsaber Parry is a Used Interrupt, your Dark Jedi will be able to come to the rescue again, and again, and again...
Cancels: A duel.

Rules: Local Trouble Battle\par A Local Trouble battle is one where a battle has been initiated by a card titled Local Trouble. During a Local Trouble battle, any other characters, vehicles, or starships at the site that are not participating in the Local Trouble battle are inactive for the duration of the battle, with two specific exceptions:\par *If a character participating in a Local Trouble battle is on an open vehicle, that vehicle is not inactive.\par *Cards that become inactive because of a Local Trouble battle are considered to be on table for the purposes of objectives.\par Remember that these cards are inactive by rule, they are not considered excluded for any game-related purpose.

This system is the Subjugated planet.\ul0 \par \b While\b0  this side up, once during each of your deploy phases, you may deploy one <> site to the Subjugated planet from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. \par \b Flip\b0  this card if your matching operatives control at least three battleground sites related to the Subjugated planet.

Your matching operatives on that planet are each forfeit +2 and, when at same site as an Imperial or AT-AT, are each power +2. When you have at least one matching operative in a battle on the Subjugated planet, you may add one battle destiny. \par \b Flip\b0  this card if you do not occupy at least two battleground sites related to the Subjugated planet.
Gametext: [Front Side]: \ul Deploy any planet system and one <> site to that system. This system is the Subjugated planet.\ul0 \par \b While\b0  this side up, once during each of your deploy phases, you may deploy one <> site to the Subjugated planet from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. \par \b Flip\b0  this card if your matching operatives control at least three battleground sites related to the Subjugated planet.\\par[Back Side]: \b While\b0  this side up, opponent's Force drains are -1. You may retrieve 1 Force whenever you deploy a matching operative to the Subjugated planet. Your matching operatives on that planet are each forfeit +2 and, when at same site as an Imperial or AT-AT, are each power +2. When you have at least one matching operative in a battle on the Subjugated planet, you may add one battle destiny. \par \b Flip\b0  this card if you do not occupy at least two battleground sites related to the Subjugated planet.
Information: Article on DeckTech, August 19th, 2007 '2nd Annual SWCCG Encyclopedia of Decks' by Brandon "Jabba_the_Ruck" Ruck\par http://www.decktech.net/starwarsccg/articles/articles.php?id=6526&view=2\par \par Idea Behind Objective: A very stupid idea by Decipher. At first, the idea was to play a deck with 25 of your planet's operatives because they were broke on their planet. Basic it worked like this. Your objective pulled the sites, then once you controlled three, you flipped. The flip side made all DS drains -1, your operatives added +1 to force drains, deployed for one, forfeit for like 4 or 5, added a destiny at all sites while you had just one operative on the planet, and you retrieved a force every time you simply deployed one to a site. They were even power +2 against an Imperial. This was totally not a Star Wars movie idea, just crap that hurt the game. The reason this objective was even made was because Lucas denied the creation for some of the card designs only weeks before the release of Special Edition. To fix this last minute problem, the Operative strategy was added without ANY play testing.\par \par SPECIAL NOTE: Because of all the problems this objective caused. Decipher created three cards that completely hurt this deck as well as an errata to the rules saying that only one operative may be at a site, anymore would be lost. They also no longer have presence, so they can't control a site by themselves. This objective is considered to be DEAD. Decipher created this idea with no thought of what they were doing. This objective is one that we all wish they had never made. It won the '98 worlds for both sides because it was a broken idea.
Rules: This objective may not start a <> site that may not deploy to a Subjugated planet.

Lore: Good-willed Mon Calamari merchant. Looking for work. Unfortunately, everywhere he goes he comes up empty handed.
Gametext: Power +X in a battle at a site, where X equals the number of cards in opponent's hand. During your deploy phase, opponent may place any number of cards in their hand in their Used Pile.
Information: Mon Calamari are:\par \par Admiral Ackbar\par Admiral Ackbar (V)\par Captain Verrack\par First Officer Thaneespi\par Loci Rosen\par Major Haash'n\par -----\par This Mon Calamari has the potential to have enormous power. He does have a drawback of allowing your opponent to recycle cards, but he will really make your opponent think how many cards he really needs in hand. After all, one more card in his hand could mean one more battle damage coming his way.\par \par But the key to using him effectively is to get him into battle when your opponent doesn't see it coming. If you deploy him to a probable battle location, you can be sure his power will be taken down a notch before the battle. You will want to use cards that let him get to a battle without you deploying him to the battle location on your turn. For example, on Cloud City you can use Path of Least Resistance to get him where he's needed, or in Jabba's Palace you could use You Will Take Me to Jabba Now.
IsPulled: Admiral Ackbar
