Lore: When a Jedi dies, the spirit spreads through the Force and touches the living.
Gametext: Deploy on table. Once per turn, may take The Force Is Strong With This One or [Death Star II] Anakin Skywalker into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. May use 2 Force to cancel You Are Beaten (unless canceling Uncontrollable Fury) or Dark Jedi Presence. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Heading For The Medical Frigate.
Pulls: Anakin Skywalker (Interrupt)\par The Force Is Strong With This One
IsPulled: The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once\par Your Insight Serves You Well\par Your Insight Serves You Well & Staging Areas
Rules: (AR-3.0, p. A-20): Pulls only [Death Star II] Anakin Skywalker.
Cancels: Dark Jedi Presence\par You Are Beaten (unless canceling Uncontrollable Fury).

Lore: \b Spy\b0  fighting for the memory of his homeworld of Alderaan. Rogue Squadron pilot. Volunteered to fly an A-wing at the Battle of Endor. Former TIE fighter pilot.
Gametext: Deploys -2 aboard Green Squadron 3. Adds 3 to power of any starfighter he pilots. When piloting Green Squadron 3 or any X-wing, draws one battle destiny if not able to otherwise.
Information: Tycho Celchu personas are:\par Tycho Celchu\par Tycho Celchu (V)\par Tycho In Green Squadron 3\par \par Rogue Squadron is:\par \par Bodhi Rook\par Commander Luke Skywalker\par Commander Luke Skywalker (V)\par Commander Narra (V)\par Commander Wedge Antilles\par Commander Wedge Antilles (V)\par Corran Horn\par Derek 'Hobbie' Klivian\par Derek 'Hobbie' Klivian (V)\par Karie Neth\par Keir Santage\par Kin Kian\par Tycho Celchu\par Tycho Celchu (V)\par Wedge Antilles, Red Squadron Leader\par Zev Senesca

Lore: Stolen Imperial Lambda-class shuttle. Supposedly carried parts and technical crew. Delivered General Solo's crack team of Rebel scouts to the forest moon of Endor.
Gametext: May deploy (and your characters may deploy aboard) even without presence of Force icons. May add 2 pilots and 6 passengers. While \ul Tydirium\ul0  is at a system location, your scouts deploy -1 aboard.
Information: Those sneaky Rebels have gone and got themselves another spy plane!\par To assist the ever popular Tantive IV, the Tydirium provides a similar ability in letting you deploy it and characters aboard without presence or Force icons. All that for only 2 Force! The only drawback is that there is no permanent pilot, so you must have a character to put aboard before you can deploy it to space.
IsPulled: All Wings Report In & Darklighter Spin\par Fly Casual
Combo: Tydirium+ Covert Landing + General Solo + Daughter Of Skywalker = This all deploys for only 8 Force, gets you power 5, 2 battle destinies and a whole lotta forfeit.
Matching: Bodhi Rook\par Daughter Of Skywalker\par General Solo
Rules: Note that any vehicle or starship with the word 'stolen' in title is always considered to be a stolen vehicle or starship respectively, regardless of owner. Also, any card with 'Stolen' in title is still considered to be 'just stolen' whenever a player steals it.

Lore: Assigned to Admiral Ozzel's Death Squadron. Attempted to capture Rebel starships fleeing the Hoth system.
Gametext: May add 6 pilots, 8 passengers, 2 vehicles and 4 TIEs. Has ship-docking capability. Permanent pilot provides ability of 1. When using Tractor Beam, adds 1 to destiny draw.
Information: Admiral Motti (V) makes unique (*) Star Destroyers power +2 and add 1 to their immunity to attrition.
IsPulled: Commander Nemet (V)\par Kuat Drive Yards
Combo: Tyrant + Imperial Helmsman\par Draw one battle destiny if not able to otherwise.

Lore: This male Brizzit, from the planet Jandoon, is hiding from the Imperials on the remote world Tatooine. He hopes to procure passage to the Outer Rim before the Empire finds him.
Gametext: May 'fly' (move) only during your deploy phase, up to two sites away, for 1 Force. Power +1 at Trash Compactor, any Dagobah site or same site as Dark Waters or Tarkin.
Information: I Thought They Smelled Bad On The Outside doubles Tzizvvt's power until he moves.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par This alien may use his landspeed only during your deploy phase. However, he may make other kinds of regular moves and unlimited moves normally.

Lore: This protocol droid served in the House of Alderaan's Diplomatic Corps. Imperials altered its programming for espionage, making the droid an unwitting \b spy\b0  for the Empire.
Gametext: Deploy on opponent's side as an Undercover spy (except that if present during a battle at a site, adds its power to Light Side). If spy's "cover is broken," the above "game text" is canceled and Light Side may use as if stolen.
Combo: U-3PO (Yoo-Threepio) + Program Trap\par -----\par U-3PO (Yoo-Threepio) + Nevar Yalnal\par -----\par U-3PO (Yoo-Threepio) + E Chu Ta
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par U-3PO's game text that adds his power to the light side is applied even though he is not participating in the battle and is inactive. This is a singular exception to the normal rules of undercover spies and participating in battle. If stolen while Undercover (e.g., by a Caller), U-3PO moves to your side of the location and becomes an Undercover spy for your opponent. The Light Side player may choose to not accept this Dark side droid when its cover is broken, in which case it becomes a Dark Side non- Undercover droid.

Lore: \b Enclosed\b0  repulsorlift landspeeder. Micro-thrusters placed around spherical hull. Seats three. Extremely maneuverable. Top speed of 160 km per hour.
Gametext: May add 1 driver and 2 passengers. May move as a 'react.'

Lore: Ugnaught assigned to determine how to use carbon-freezing on humans. Placed in charge of the Ugnaught workers on Cloud City. Formerly enslaved by humans.
Gametext: Power +2 at Trash Compactor, Droid Junkheap, Incinerator or Carbonite Chamber. Functions as a leader if present with another Ugnaught. Where present, other Ugnaughts are forfeit +2 and double their bonus to Carbon-Freezing destiny.
Information: Here is another one of the Carbon-Freezing enhancers from Cloud City. This is the card that will allow the Dark Side to play with only three to five non-unique ugnaughts in their deck, and still have a relatively decent chance of pulling off freezing.\par \par The power +2 bonus is nice, but not really why this character is on the table. Another small, but nice feature is that if pressed into service, Ugloste is a warrior that can be armed and sent out with a We Have A Prisoner in hand to go and do the capture work to get a potential freezing candidate. The bonus that he gives to the other Ugnaughts with him gives the Dark Side a decent chance of coming out of the battle without too much trouble. With the added bonus from Prepare The Chamber to battles, they may even be a force to be reckoned with.\par \par The real advantage of this guy is that he doubles the additions by the Ugnaughts, making freezing a real possibility when taken in conjunction with other cards such as Prepare The Chamber and Carbonite Chamber Console.
IsPulled: Carbonite Chamber Console

Lore: Cheap manual labor from Gentes in the Anoat system. Make up Cloud City's second largest population. Responsible for maintenance and menial chores throughout the city.
Gametext: When at Carbonite Chamber, \b cumulatively\b0  adds 1 to each Carbon-Freezing destiny draw. During your control phase, may lose 1 Force from hand to search your Lost Pile and take one weapon or device into hand.
Information: Here is an answer for everybody that wants to know how to draw more than 10 for Carbon-Freezing destiny. Much in the way that Death Star Gunners and Rebel Techs are necessary to make a Commence Primary Ignition or Attack Run deck go, these little guys are the key to making Rebels 'well preserved'. The Ugnaught advantage though, is that there are some other cards that allow them to play a more useful role.\par \par Obviously, their prime purpose in the game is to pull off Carbon-Freezing. To do this, they each add one. Throw in Ugloste and this bonus just soars. What should not be overlooked is the ability to sacrifice a card to go and get a few things to facilitate the freezing process. This means that you can lose the key cards to the freezing process early, knowing that you can get them back later in the game. Get the Carbonite Chamber Console and not only do you get the bonus to freezing destiny, but suddenly more Ugnaughts, and even the Carbon-Freezing effect itself show up. Prepare The Chamber also helps both the destiny draw, and the Ugnaughts themselves.\par \par Another advantage to these guys is that they can help outfit your bounty hunting crew. Who wouldn't lose two Force to give IG-88 a Light Repeating Blaster Rifle an a Portable Fusion Generator. Give him some Binders and he can do all the collection work for you. Also, with Ugloste, Ugnaughts provide a decent little fighting force on their own, especially with Prepare The Chamber.
Pulls: On weapon from Lost Pile.\par On device from Lost Pile.
IsPulled: Carbonite Chamber Console
Combo: Ugnaughts + Prepare The Chamber + Carbonite Chamber Console + Ugloste\par A guaranteed freezing draw.\par -----\par Ugnaughts + weapons + bounty hunters. These guys can serve as the ultimate armorers. You don't have to worry about hanging on to combinations of weapon cards until you actually have the warriors to use them.

Lore: Imperial law had no place in the Hutt's domain.
Gametext: Deploy on your side of table. While no Rebels are at any Jabba's Palace sites, at all such sites: Imperials are deploy +2, Bo Shuda may not be canceled, Expand The Empire is canceled and your non-unique aliens are each forfeit +1. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Heading For The Medical Frigate.
IsPulled: The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once
Combo: Bo Shuda + Uh-oh! + Tatooine: Jabba's Palace (LS)
Cancels: Expand The Empire

Lore: "Jabba! This is your last chance. Free us or die."
Gametext: Deploy on your side of table. While you occupy at least 3 battlegrounds or opponent occupies no battlegrounds, you lose no more than 2 Force from each Force drain or 'insert' card. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Heading For The Medical Frigate.\par \par Ultimatum is arguably the most powerful card in the entire expansion. With the ability to force your opponent out into the open, decks can now be more focused on battling, rather than Force draining. The Light Side might be a little bit more prepared for this event, especially in space. With Captain Han and the Falcon, you can be prepared for just about any Dark side assault. On the ground, none match Son Of Skywalker's versatility. With a deck made for fighting, Ultimatum can be the key to bringing your opponent to you, rather than waiting for him.
IsPulled: The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once
Combo: Ultimatum in a Teamwork deck -- The ultimate fighting deck gets infinitely better with the addition of this equalizer. Not only can you drop a nasty surprise on your opponent in the form of multiple destiny adding interrupts, but you can weaken his strategy if he does not fall for you ruse. Either way, you have the advantage.\par \par Ultimatum in an Asteroid Sanctuary deck -- Note that neither Resistance nor Ultimatum affect Asteroid Sanctuary in the slightest, giving the Asteroid Sanctuary deck a slight edge over its opponent, who is probably using either Force drain or inserts as a damage dealing strategy. Load up with Tentacles and Controls to stop Alter, and protect the Asteroids. Add Rycar's Run for some Force retrieval.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par The text of this card comes into effect as an automatic action when you lose your second Force (and meet all other requirements of the card). For example, if you are being drained for 5 Force and you satisfy the battleground requirements of Ultimatum as well as having It Could Be Worse in hand and 2 Force saved. If you choose to play It Could Be Worse to reduce the Force loss by 2, you have not lost any Force to the drain, and must still lose 2 Force before Ultimatum will take effect (and you then will not have to lose any more Force).

Lore: "Jabba! This is your last chance. Free us or die."
Gametext: Plays on table. While you occupy at least 3 battlegrounds or opponent occupies no battlegrounds, you lose no more than 2 Force from each Force drain or 'insert' card.

Lore: Klatooinian born into slavery to Desilijic Hutt clan on Shawti. \b Musician\b0. Works as a \b spy\b0  for Jabba at his desert fortress while playing drums for visiting bands.
Gametext: Power +2 at a Jabba's Palace site. Each of your other musicians at same site is power +2 and immune to attrition < 3. Immune to attrition < 4.
IsPulled: Ak-rev\par Murttoc Yine
Combo: Umpass-Stay + Nevar Yalnal

Lore: Even a Jedi cannot always foresee future events.
Gametext: Use 3 Force. Each player places hand onto Reserve Deck (if possible), then places Used Pile onto Reserve Deck; reshuffle. Each player then draws cards from Reserve Deck equal to the number of cards just placed from hand onto Reserve Deck (if any).
Information: Combo Card: Sense & Uncertain Is The Future

Lore: The rage of the Dark Lord.
Gametext: Deploy on Vader. He is power +2, but neither adds 1 to battle destiny nor allows Tarkin to cancel destiny. Opponent loses 2 Force at end of each of opponent's turns in which Vader did not battle and you had a character of ability > 3 on table. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: This card is a must in decks that intend to confront the Dark Side in a direct confrontation at sites. Uncontrollable Fury could also be useful at systems, but the benefits of Vader (especially when combined with Tarkin) are not quite as powerful at systems and sectors due to the fact the Light Side cannot lose the forfeit value of cards due to Vader and his lightsaber while in space.\par \par Since the Premiere edition of the game, Light Side players have been searching for a way to counter the deadly combination of Grand Moff Tarkin and Darth Vader. Some solutions that have worked to one extent or another have been Demotion, Tarkin Seeker and playing space decks. An opinion that some top ranked players hold is that Vader is wasted in space when compared with his devastating effectiveness at sites. Uncontrollable Fury is another tool in this war. While there is a Dark Side card that can cancel it, the power of Uncontrollable Fury probably makes it more than worth the risk.\par \par There are numerous avoidance strategies that can make use of the Force loss part of the card. The easiest of these is just to use Nabrun Leids to move away from Vader in each of the Dark Side's battle phases, and cause them to lose two Force per opponent's turn. Of course, that requires the Dark player to use Vader, but he is usually to good to pass up.\par -----\par Dark side card against direct damage: Imperial Decree (V).
IsPulled: Clash Of Sabers\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once\par Wokling (V)

Lore: With the Rebels' limited resources and small numbers, desperate strategies are often required.
Gametext: During your control phase, target a vehicle with armor present with your warrior. Draw destiny. If warrior has a Concussion Grenade or a lightsaber, add 3 to destiny draw (7 if both). Vehicle (and grenade) lost if total destiny > armor.
Combo: Under Attack + Concussion Grenade

Lore: The Empire maintains a network of spies attempting to infiltrate the Rebel Alliance or disinform their operatives.
Gametext: Deploy on your spy at a site and cross spy to opponent's side. Spy is now Undercover. During your deploy phase, may voluntarily "break cover" (lose Effect) if at a site. (Immune to Alter.)
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Lore: Alliance Intelligence expends considerable resources to infiltrate the Imperial military bureaucracy, but the ISB's security sweeps make these shadowy operations dangerous.
Gametext: Deploy on your spy at a site and cross spy to opponent's side. Spy is now Undercover. During your deploy phase, may voluntarily "break cover" (lose Effect) if at a site. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: I you control Bothawui, Undercover is immune to Hutt Smooch.
IsPulled: Mercenary Armor (V)\par Tamtel Skreej\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once\par Wokling (V)

Lore: Influence, like any commodity, has a price in the Outer Rim territories.
Gametext: Deploy on a Tatooine site. Your Force generation here is +1. Opponent may not cancel or modify Force drains at each Tatooine battleground site where you have two aliens with different card titles. At any time, you may use 2 Force to raise your converted Tatooine site to top.
IsPulled: Seeking An Audience\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once\par Wokling (V)

Lore: "Sir! Sir! I've isolated the reverse power flux coupling!"
Gametext: Use 2 Force to take one Interrupt into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.
Pulls: One Interrupt.

Lore: "Get the gun! Point it at the deck!"
Gametext: If an AT-AT, an AT-ST, Jabba's Sail Barge or Planet Defender Ion Cannon has just been lost at a site, draw destiny. All cards with that destiny number at that site are lost.

Lore: With mounting pressure from superior forces, the Rebellion sometimes has to abandon its crippled equipment in order to simply get its personnel out alive.
Gametext: During your turn, target an opponent's unpiloted starship present at a system, or an opponent's unpiloted vehicle. Target is lost (along with any cards aboard it). OR Cancel Hyper Escape, Power Pivot, or Out Of Commission.
Cancels: Hyper Escape\par Power Pivot\par Out Of Commission\par Out Of Commission & Transmission Terminated

Lore: Fierce Tusken Raider. Ransacks homes and moisture farms on the borders of Mos Espa.
Gametext: Deploys only on Tatooine. While at Tusken Canyon, Jundland Wastes or same Tatooine site as URoRRuR'R'R, adds 2 to each of your battle destiny draws at Tatooine sites where you have a Tusken Raider.
IsPulled: Bantha Fodder

Lore: \b Leader\b0  of a Tusken Raider tribe. Unafraid of machines. Skilled hunter and marksman. Raids moisture farms for water. Roams the Jundland Wastes in search of unwary travelers.
Gametext: Deploys only on Tatooine. When at same site as another Tusken Raider, may draw one battle destiny if not able to otherwise.
IsPulled: Bantha Fodder
MatchingWeapon: URoRRuR'R'R's Hunting Rifle

Lore: Raised by RR'uruurr for personal use by URoRRuR'R'R. Alpha male of his bantha herd. Has trampled many Jawas. Nicknamed 'Rrr'ur'R.'
Gametext: May add 2 'riders' (passengers). Ability = 1/2. Adds 1 to power of each of your Tusken Raiders and other banthas present. When 'ridden' by URoRRuR'R'R, adds one battle destiny.

Lore: Owning a hunting rifle is an important status symbol in Tusken culture. URoRRuR'R'R scavenged this weapon from a starship wreck near Anchorhead.
Gametext: Use 1 Force to deploy on URoRRuR'R'R or Chief Bast, 3 on your non-droid character. May target a character or creature using 1 Force. Draw destiny. Subtract 1 if targeting a character. Add 2 if targeting a creature. Target hit if total destiny > defense value.
Information: Can be deployed from Reserve Deck on a trooper with Blast Points.
IsPulled: Jabba's Through With You\par Kashyyyk: Slaving Camp Headquarters (V)\par Mara Jade, The Emperor's Hand
MatchingWeapon: Chief Bast\par URoRRuR'R'R

Gametext: If one of your Jawas is at the same location as any Utinni Effect, 'steal' that Utinni Effect into your hand, to use or lose as your own. OR Cancel any Interrupt or Effect with 'Jawa' in the card name.

Gametext: Deploys only on Tatooine. Once during each of your control phases, may lose 1 Force to steal into hand one transport vehicle, character weapon or device from opponent's Lost Pile.
IsPulled: Aved Luun to deploy to same location.\par Soth Petikkin (when at a Jabba's Palace site you control).

Lore: Sought to extinguish all Jedi. Former student of Obi-Wan Kenobi. Seduced by the dark side of the Force.

Gametext: USED: Add 1 to your just-drawn lightsaber weapon destiny draw. LOST: If a duel was just initiated, place the top card of your Used Pile on top of your Reserve Deck.

Lore: "We would be honored if you would join us."

Lore: Vader sought to hunt down and destroy all Jedi. After completing the circle with Obi-Wan, he turned his attention to the young Skywalker.
Gametext: During your move phase, if Vader moves to Luke's site from an adjacent site, begin a duel between them. Each adds two destiny to power. Winner retrieves lost Force equal to the difference. Loser loses same amount of Force, plus the character.

Lore: Customized transport of Lord Vader. Employs advanced sensor jamming gear. Modified with enhanced tactical displays constructed to the Dark Lord's specifications.
Gametext: May add 1 pilot and 4 passengers. Permanent pilot aboard provides ability of 2. Moves for free. While Vader aboard, opponent must have ability > 5 to draw battle destiny at same system. May not Tallon Roll.

Lore: Essential for life on desert planets. Condenses water vapor from atmosphere. Has purification filters and coolant tanks. Protects against drought and harsh conditions.

Gametext: Deploys only on Tatooine. During your control phase, if at a Jabba's Palace site, may use 2 Force to make a 'wager'. Both players draw one destiny. Player with lower number loses 1 Force.

Lore: General of the AT-AT assault armor division sent by Darth Vader to crush the Rebellion on Hoth. Cold and ruthless.

Lore: Launches and detonates when activated by a passing metallic mass or the repulsorlift field of an approaching speeder. The shrapnel can hit even the quickest craft.

Lore: Mine controlled by microcircuitry calibrated to ignore infantry and creatures. Explodes only when triggered by metallic vehicles.
Gametext: Deploy at same exterior site as your mining droid. 'Explodes' if starfighter (use 5 as defense value) or non-creature vehicle deploys or moves to or across same site. Draw destiny. Target lost if destiny +2 > defense value. Vehicle Mine is also lost.

Lore: Assigned by Jabba to work with Hermi Odle. Former technician for the Empire. Developed a method to remotely control seekers. Plotting to kill Jabba.
Gametext: When at a site you control, allows your Seekers to deploy free there. Also allows your Seekers to move for free and to ignore any or all potential target(s) whenever you choose.

Lore: Part of Darth Vader's Death Squadron. Support vessel for the fleet's starfighters. Cargo areas converted into hangar space for additional TIE fighters.
Gametext: May add 6 pilots, 8 passengers, 1 vehicle and 6 TIEs. Has ship-docking capability. Permanent pilot provides ability of 2. Your TIE/lns are forfeit +2 at same location. Power +2 at Nal Hutta.

Combo: Vengeance + Imperial Helmsman\par Draw one battle destiny if not able to otherwise.

Lore: SoroSuub BD-1 Cutter vibro-ax. Powered by an ultrasonic generator concealed in the shaft. Jabba's skiff guards use them to prod victims into the Sarlacc's nest.
Gametext: Use 3 Force to deploy on any alien warrior. Adds 1 to power. May target a character using 1 Force. Both players draw destiny. Target immediately excluded from battle if warrior's power + your destiny > target's power + opponent's destiny.
IsPulled: Jabba's Through With You\par Mara Jade, The Emperor's Hand\par Snoova

Lore: Vibrating blade powered by an energy cell hidden within the shaft. Used by many moisture farmers to prod banthas and other animals.
Gametext: Use 3 Force to deploy on any alien warrior. Adds 1 to power. May target a character using 1 Force. Both players draw destiny. Target immediately excluded from battle if warrior's power + your destiny > target's power + opponent's destiny.
Information: The Vibro-Ax seems like a better card for the Dark Side at first. However, the edges that the Light Side has can make it just as deadly for the Light as the Dark. First, the Light Side has the highest power for ability alien in the game, in Chewbacca. Granted, Kitik Keed'kak has a higher power, because of his low ability and low Forfeit, he rarely, if ever makes it into play, especially for his massive deploy cost. Therefore, Chewie can reasonably swing a Vibro-Ax with impunity, with his power boosted marginally by the Ax, and when present with Han, his power becomes 8. Also, the Light Side has considerably better destiny than the Dark, making hitting with the Vibro-Ax even better.
IsPulled: Portable Scanner
Combo: Vibro-Ax + Clash Of Sabers\par Taking your opponent's characters out of battle can be a terrific ability, and this combo can not only take out Vader, but Tarkin as well! Give Chewie a Vibro-Ax, to swing at Tarkin, and have Luke or Obi-Wan Clash Vader.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par The destiny drawn by the player whose character is being targeted by the Vibro-Ax is not a weapon destiny.

Lore: With enough political support, any number of devious plans can be put into motion.
Gametext: During your control phase, draw destiny. If destiny > 2, draw up to X cards (maximum 4) from Reserve Deck, where X = your total politics at Galactic Senate minus opponent's total politics at Galactic Senate.

Lore: "Vote now! Vote now! Vote now!"
Gametext: During your control phase, draw destiny. If destiny > 2, draw up to X cards (maximum 4) from Reserve Deck, where X = your total politics at Galactic Senate minus opponent's total politics at Galactic Senate.
Information: Do you like drawing extra cards? Do you like recycling cards? If so, then this is the card for your Light Senator deck.\par No matter whether the game just started, or it's almost over, this is never a bad card. Early on, you can play this and if you're lucky, you can draw some extra cards, but even if not, you've still recycled a 5. In the mid to late game when you may have set up some destinies, this can give you some guaranteed card draws, if you're in control of the senate. And what's even better, if you've somehow lost control of the Senate, you can still play it as a recyclable 5.

Lore: As there are very few local authorities on Dagobah, peeping astromechs can get away with just about anything.
Gametext: Name an Interrupt card. Opponent must reveal entire Used Pile, without shuffling. Then you choose: USED: Opponent must lose 1 Force for each copy of that Interrupt found there. LOST: Each copy of that interrupt found there is lost.
Combo: Voyeur + Trinto Duaba + Dune Sea Sabacc (or any Sabacc really)\par Play Sabacc to get cards in their used pile, then the other 2 Interrupts to make them lose force/other cards. (maxbeedo)

Lore: Security officer from Kiffex searching for the Tonnika sisters. In love with one of them, he's not sure which.
Gametext: Adds 2 to power of anything he pilots. Twice during battle at same system, may use 2 Force to add 2 to any destiny of 2. If present with Tonnika Sisters, Vul and Tonnika Sisters are lost.
Information: Ok, all of the players who have played longer than a year raise your hands. Ok, all you players who have dealt with the horrific Tonnika Sisters raise your hands. Thought so. Despite the fact that the Tonnika Sisters came from way back when, they are still a headache to all Lightside players to date. Well, now it is the Light players turn. Enter, Vul Tazaenne. This guy is actually pretty good in the navy. As a starship pilot he can not only add 2 to the power of any starship he pilots but, can add 2 to any destiny of 2 for only 2 force, twice per battle. What that means in English is that the you can modify a battle significantly if you so choose. Not bad for a destiny 2 card with 2 ability.
Combo: Vul Tazaenne + Red Leader in Red 1/Gold Leader in Gold 1 + 2 Landing Claws + Kiffex = The coolness of this is it's simplicity. This is not a 6 card combo, but a situation that you can prepare for. You will have the ability to drain for two at Kiffex while keeping a safe distance from your opponent. If they decide to battle you, hide. If you draw any of these cards for destiny, they are all a two's. Also, if you control Kiffex itself with the two starships, Vul will add 4 to all 4's. Not bad for a little 2 deploy character.\par -----\par Vul Tazaene + Kiffex
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par See Kiffex.\par \par (AR 1.7.1, B-10)\par Kiffex\par While this system's game text "doubles" a character, it means that:\par - Every printed number on that card is doubled (thus a 1 becomes a 2, a 2 becomes a 4, etc.)\par - Every printed indication of number of uses is doubled (thus "once" becomes "twice," "twice" becomes "four times" etc.). Apply any additional modifiers and other effects to the new values (e.g., a doubled Tonnika Sisters with Mandalorian Armor is power = 6, and a Vul Tazaene that has competed Jedi Test 3 will be ability 4, not ability 6).
Cancels: If present with Tonnika Sisters, Vul and Tonnika Sisters are lost.

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par When capturing a just forfeited character using this Dark Side Effect, that character is captured after applying forfeit value but before being placed on the Lost Pile. When captured, the characters values that would normally be restored upon leaving table (e.g., forfeit being reduced by 2, power being reduced to 0) has those values reset. In this way, cards deployed on that character (for example, Bounty or a weapon) are not placed in the Lost Pile. Additionally, if the card was 'hit', it is no longer 'hit'. This is a specific exception to the just lost ruling.\par This Interrupt's first function may capture a character lost or forfeited from a system or sector, if you have a potential escort available aboard a vehicle or starship at that location.

CardName: We're All Gonna Be A Lot Thinner!
Lore: Trash compactors crush waste before it is jettisoned into space. Magnetically sealed to prevent leakage. R2-D2 saved the day by shutting down compactor 3263827.
Gametext: Everything in Trash Compactor is crushed (Lost).

Lore: Threepio's many misadventures often threatened his continued operation. The luckless protocol droid developed a healthy sense of cynicism, and a keen grasp of the obvious.
Gametext: If you have less than 15 Life Force, play during opponent's control phase. For remainder of turn, each time you must lose Force, the loss is cut in half (round up). If R2-D2 or C-3PO on table, round down.

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par This Interrupt is not a response to a Force drain.\par -----\par When applying this automatic force reduction modifier in combination with other automatic modifiers (such as Honor of the Jedi) the halving from We're Doomed is applied first before the other cards take effect. This is a specific exception to the rule that all automatic modifiers are applied to a value instantaneously.

Lore: Complex recursive algorithms are used by Trade Federation starships to seek out and destroy enemies within targeting range.
Gametext: Once during battle, target a participating starfighter present with your droid starfighter. Draw destiny. If destiny > target's defense value, target 'hit,' OR If opponent's starfighter was just 'hit' where your droid starfighter is present, activate up to 4 Force.
Information: Can't find your droid starfighter laser cannons? Then you probably didn't put them in your deck. So instead, go for the Used interrupt version of droid starfighter laser fire. It's only a basic destiny > defense value, which can be tough against high maneuver Naboo fighters or X-Wings, but even with a miss, it's a recycled 5. If you have weaponry working for you already, use it for a little activation. If you think you are up to the challenge, see if you can hit with one We're Hit, Artoo, then play another to activate 4 Force.

Thus, cards that are not participating in the battle or that do not have a forfeit value (e.g., a Vaporator) are ignored.

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par This Utinni Effect may target Luke even if he is on Dagobah (as implied by the Jedi Test restriction). We're The Bait is canceled if the captive or frozen character it is deployed on is released.

Lore: Vader confiscated Han's blaster, his ship, his Wookiee, his girl and his only hope of escape.
Gametext: USED: Search your Used Pile, take one weapon into hand and reshuffle. LOST: If a battle was just initiated, one of your characters of ability > 3 present may 'steal' one character weapon present.
Information: When using this card as a Used Interrupt, you may search your Used Pile. Doesn't sound overly interesting. However, after deploying something like an Executor, or a normal star destroyer with pilots, you should have an interesting Used Pile. If you have plenty weapons in your deck, chances are good that you find a weapon there. This is also a very strong point, as you can take ONE weapon. It does not specify which weapon. Find a Superlaser there ? Take it. Vader needs his custom slice-toy and it's in the Used Pile ? Pick out Vader's Lightsaber and take it into your hand. Want to arm that star destroyer ? Weapon Levitate the Turbolaser Battery or Ion Cannon you see in your Used Pile. The possibilities are only limited by the weapons in your deck.\par \par There is another use, the Lost Interrupt variant. For fun I'll give an example which actually happened. I had an unarmed Darth Vader at a site. Here comes Obi-Wan with a generic Jedi Lightsaber (his own toy was not deployed yet). Obi starts to battle and suddenly he feels the lightsaber wrenched from his grip, sees it flying through the room and into Darth Vaders hands. The last thing Obi-Wan ever saw, was Darth Vader slicing him with Obi's own surrogate toy.\par \par In the game, Obi-Wan started the battle and I played Weapon Levitation as a Lost Interrupt. I snatched the Jedi Lightsaber and, as it can be used by any warrior, used it to slice Obi-Wan to ribbons. However, things get a little more interesting. The game text states, that you may 'steal' one character weapon present. OK, so you will not run off with a Planet Defender Ion Cannon. However, did you see Luke waving his Blaster Pistol (and you fear he will target you, to make Darth lose the immunity to attrition) ? 'Steal' the pistol. It is a character weapon. Do you see Djas Puhr against a Light Side character with a Blaster Rifle and your opponent starts the fight ? Use Weapon Levitation to 'steal' the rifle. You see, the great part is, that neither specific weapons, nor specific characters are mentioned. Any character of ability >3 can steal any character weapon (so you might even get a weapon back thet the Light Side once stole from you !).\par \par In short, a good card to include in any deck, especially if you have a lot of weapons, a lot of ability 4+ characters, ... or both.\par \par Strong points:\par * Weapon Levitation = Destiny 4 - good to upgrade average destiny, good to draw destiny.\par * Weapon Levitation = Two cards for the price of one (Used and Lost variant).\par * Weapon Levitation = Uncommon, thus it should not be too hard to get.\par * Weapon Levitation = Surprise, as in, surprise your opponent by using his weapons against him, or at least get your weapons fast.\par \par \par Weak points:\par * Weapon Levitation = Not immune, so a Sense could ruin this little plan.\par * Weapon Levitation = Unique. You can't search a weapon, not find it and then use a second Weapon Levitation to 'steal' in one turn.
Pulls: One weapon from Used Pile.
Combo: Weapon Levitation  Control = Who said anything about 'Sense' ?\par -----\par Weapon Levitation + opponent's Polarized Negative Power Coupling = You SEE your Used Pile, you know what cards go there.\par -----\par Weapon Levitation + many weapon cards in your deck = many weapons on the table fast, destiny 4 card recycled each time.\par -----\par Weapon Levitation + many characters of ability >3 = You do not need your own weapons if you have enough Weapon Levitations.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par You may not initiate a Weapon Levitation (Lost function) if the stealing character is incapable of "carrying" a weapon. For example, a B'omarr Monk, or a Disarmed character.

Lore: A Jedi is taught to use the anger of his opponents (and their weapons) against them.
Gametext: USED: Search your Used Pile, take one weapon into hand and reshuffle. LOST: Cancel You Are Beaten. OR If a battle was just initiated, one of your characters of ability > 3 present may steal one character weapon present.
Information: This is a multi-useful, unique Light Used or Lost Interrupt with a destiny of 4. Its Used function searches through your Used Pile to take one weapon into hand and reshuffle. This can come in handy when looking for that elusive matching weapon that could make a difference in a key battle. One of its Lost functions flat-out cancels the nasty interrupt You Are Beaten, a card that should be canceled when at all possible. Apart from Sense, this is the best way to cancel that Dark interrupt. The final Lost use of Weapon Levitation plays if a battle was just initiated, allowing one of your characters present with ability greater than three to steal one character weapon present. Stealing a troublesome weapon may come in handy from time to time, but all three functions and its attractive destiny number make it a good utility card to include in certain decks.\par \par The Dark Side has enjoyed this fantastic interrupt since Cloud City, and, finally, the Light Side gets its turn. Weapon Levitation can be a great way to swipe an important weapon such as Vader's Lightsaber, without putting yourself in too much of a random situation (like Sabacc.) While Luke cannot use Vader's Lightsaber, he can prevent it from being deployed again. He can also steal other important weapons like Thermal Detonators, Boba Fett's Blaster Rifle, and Dengar's Modified Riot Gun.
Pulls: One weapon from Used Pile.
IsPulled: Yoda's Hope
Combo: Weapon Levitation + Sabacc -- Using these two strategies together, you can completely deprive your opponent of weapons, but there are more subtle parts to this strategy. Sabacc is a great way to manipulate your own Used Pile, so that if you draw Anakin's Lightsaber with Sabacc, you can use Weapon Levitation to get it back out of your Used Pile.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par You may not initiate a Weapon Levitation (Lost function) if the stealing character is incapable of "carrying" a weapon. For example, a B'omarr Monk, or a Disarmed character.
Cancels: You Are Beaten

Lore: When Vader dueled Luke at Cloud City, he fought a son trained by his former master and a weapon constructed by his former self.
Gametext: USED: If a lightsaber was just used to enhance a Force drain, place it in owner's Used Pile. LOST: Place any or all of your devices and character weapons on table in your Used Pile.
Information: A unique Used or Lost Interrupt with a 5 destiny, using one of these in a deck helps to make weapons and devices less card-intensive to make use of. First, the Used function plays when a lightsaber was just used to enhance a Force drain, and puts that lightsaber into the owner's Used Pile. This is very obnoxious to do after Mara or Son Of Skywalker has used their "once per game" ability. Putting an opponent's lightsaber into the Used Pile is beneficial since it takes away the Force drain bonus for the following turn, and it removes the battle / duel advantage that a saber provides. Also, late in the game, you can put one of your lightsabers into your Used Pile to help boost your differential. As a Lost Interrupt, this works even better for this purpose, as you may place any or all of your devices and character weapons on table into your Used Pile. These counterparts are a must in any deck utilizing a quantity of devices and character weapons, and allows them to be used without the disadvantage of being too card-intensive. For a funny Light Side combo, put a bunch on high destiny devices into the Used Pile while Descent Into The Dark is out, then battle or Surprise Assault.

Information: Startable with Heading For The Medical Frigate.\par -----\par This is a card that adds a lot of strategy and fun to the Cloud City set. While you're battling on Cloud City, there is always the danger of your characters being thrown into a ventilation shaft and winding up dangling from a small metal rod below the city.\par \par Since there's only room for one on that rod, it's really in your best interest to control the Bespin: Cloud City sector, and get your characters out of there as fast as possible. Otherwise, the next person to get thrown (or to voluntarily jump) off of a catwalk is going to knock your character into the clouds below.

Information: Targets of this card:\par \par Admiral Ozzel\par Admiral Ozzel (V)\par Captain Needa\par Captain Sarkli\par Colonel Wullf Yularen\par Colonel Wullf Yularen (V)\par Corporal Misik\par Corporal Vandolay\par Corporal Vandolay (V)\par Darth Vader\par Darth Vader (V)\par Darth Vader, Dark Lord Of The Sith\par Dash Rendar\par Elite Squadron Stormtrooper\par Grand Moff Tarkin\par Imperial Lieutenant Grond\par Lieutenant Grond (V)\par Lieutenant Renz\par Lieutenant Renz (V)\par Lord Vader\par Moff Jerjerrod\par Myn Kyneugh\par Royal Guard\par Sim Aloo\par Sim Aloo (V)\par Stormtrooper
IsPulled: The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once

Lore: When Qui-Gon got away, Maul knew it would only be a matter of time until the two of them would meet again.
Gametext: If opponent just initiated a duel against one of your non-captive Jedi, deploy on that Jedi. Cancel the duel and relocate this Jedi to an adjacent site. Your duel destiny draws are each +1. (Immune to Control.)
Information: There are two major types of anti-dueling cards - "escape the duel" cards and "help win the duel" cards. This Immediate Effect walks a fine line between them both!\par \par Initially, it provides you with a duel canceler. Unlike A Jedi's Resilience, though, you must make your cancel decision as the duel is initiated. This one does not give you the option to await the outcome!\par \par But it does come with an added benefit. Now that you know your Jedi is being targeted, and your assailant has been drawn out (most likely? the duel-happy Darth Maul), use this knowledge to your advantage to put all your Jedi on high alert! All your duel destiny draws are now +1, regardless which character is under attack. And it will last as long as you can keep the Jedi with What Was It? on him alive!
IsPulled: Don't Do That Again\par Don't Do That Again - Defensive Shield\par Don't Do That Again (V) - Defensive Shield\par Harc Seff (V)\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once
Cancels: A duel

Gametext: Deploy on table. While no card here, may cancel a Force drain by placing a non-unique destroyer droid here from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. During your deploy phase, may use 5 Force to deploy (for free) a destroyer droid from here, as if from hand.

Lore: Whipids originate from Toola in the Kaelta system, a planet extremely distant from its sun. Accustomed to hunting for prey in the near dark and the bitter cold.
Gametext: Power +2 on Hoth. Forfeit +2 under "nighttime conditions." When at a site, if opponent cancels Sunsdown at the related system, causes Effect to go to Used Pile and may retrieve 2 Force.

Lore: "I must've hit pretty close to the mark to get her all riled up like that, huh kid?"
Gametext: Cancel Scruffy-Looking Nerf Herder or I'd Just As Soon Kiss A Wookiee or Furry Fury or This Is Just Wrong or Death Mark or Mournful Roar or Takeel or Ket Maliss. OR Double Rennek's power for remainder of turn.

Lore: "Look! One of ours, out of the main hold!"
Gametext: Take a unique (*)N-1 starfighter into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. OR If a battle was just initiated at a system where opponent has a droid starfighter, all droid starfighters at that system are power -1 for remainder of turn.
Pulls: A unique (*) N-1 starfighter\par Bravo 1\par Bravo 2\par Bravo 3\par Bravo 4\par Bravo 5\par Bravo Fighter

Lore: Lacking foresight, Luke suffered the consequences of rushing into battle unprepared.
Gametext: USED: Cancel Noble Sacrifice, Gift Of The Mentor or Old Ben. LOST: If Luke is defending a battle, draw one destiny. Subtract that amount from opponent's attrition and total power (cannot fall below zero).
Information: The Dark Side often has a problem with farmboy Luke and friends playing interrupts to enhance destiny draws. From Gift of the Mentor to Skywalkers, the Light Side has plenty of interrupts to throw at you. There are times when you just plain don't have enough Senses and Alters to take care of the job. So, what do you do?\par \par There are a number of what we like to call "tension" cards that the Dark Side may use to its advantage. These cards show relationships between Light Side characters at vulnerable moments. Scruffy Looking Nerf Herder is the first and best-known of these tension cards. In Scruffy Looking Nerf Herder, Leia and Han's usual strong bond hits a weak spot and allows the Dark Side to draw two destiny and to subtract that amount from the Light Side opponent's attrition and total power.\par \par Since every Light Side deck uses Luke in one form or another, including a card to counter an opponent using one of the personas of Luke is a good idea. Why Didn't You Tell Me? cancels Gift Of The Mentor and the popular Force regeneration card, Noble Sacrifice. It's a rare game when Yoda doesn't bite the big one because of Noble Sacrifice (gaining the Light Side 9 Force!), so canceling it is good idea.\par \par In a battle against Luke, Why Didn't You Tell Me can hamper your opponent significantly. Some of the Light Side strategies deal with simply deploying a main character, and trying to chip away at the an opposing vehicle, character, or starship, and hope that the other cards' Forfeit guides them through the Force loss. With a good destiny draw, this hope can be at least stemmed, as those cards battle destiny dwindles from a five or six to a mere one or two. Not a problem, simply add another counter to your Septoid Droid.
Combo: Why Didn't You Tell Me? + cheap characters of 2 Power, such as DS-61-2 = One of the more annoying things that happens in a game is when your opponent notices you've played a 2 Power pilot and sacrifices Yoda. Why Didn't You Tell Me? gets rid of that fairly easily.
Cancels: Gift Of The Mentor\par Noble Sacrifice\par Old Ben

Lore: Ewok \b scout\b0. Son of Shodu and Deej. Found Leia and befriended her. Persuaded his tribe to help.
Gametext: Deploys only on Endor. Power and forfeit +1 for each (Light Side Force icon) at same Endor site. When in battle, may target one opponent's character present. Draw destiny. Target excluded from battle if destiny > ability.
IsPulled: General Crix Madine\par Soth Petikkin (when at a Jabba's Palace site you control).

Lore: A Snivvian on Cloud City, working for Planet Dreams, Inc. Terraforms asteroids, creating habitable atmospheres. Responsible for the aesthetics of the created environments.
Gametext: Power +1 if with Zutton. During your control phase, may use 1 Force to place one asteroid sector from hand onto Used Pile, search Reserve Deck, take one site into hand and reshuffle.
Pulls: One site when placing one asteroid sector onto Used Pile.

Lore: Bought Luke's landspeeder for Spaceport Speeders. A Vuvrian female. \b Gambler\b0  who owes Jabba 1,000 credits in wagering debts. Speaks many languages.
Gametext: During your control phase, may use 1 Force to target an opponent's unoccupied transport vehicle or droid present. Draw destiny. If destiny > target's destiny number, use Force equal to target's deploy cost to 'purchase' target (use as if stolen).
Combo: Deploy her at the Cloud City: Incinerator and couple her with Spaceport Speeders and an R2-X2 (Artoo-Extoo) and you have a great combination which allows you to activate a lot of Force without losing any cards. Place her in a Cloud City Sabacc based deck and you have a gambler and a great draw during Sabacc games.\par ------\par Wioslea + Cloud City: Incinerator + Spaceport Speeders + R2-X2 (Artoo-Extoo) \par Create a great Force generator! \par ------\par Wioslea + Cloud City Sabacc\par Helps you win Sabacc games!

Lore: Male Jawa. \b Leader\b0  of a large tribe of Jawas. Plotting with Jabba to take control of a neighboring tribe's territory.
Gametext: Deploys only on Tatooine. Your Jawa Pack is not unique (*), is doubled, deploys free (or for 6 Force from each player) and \b cumulatively\b0  affects your Jawa's forfeit. While at Audience Chamber or Jawa Camp, all your other Jawas are power +2.
IsPulled: Herat to deploy to same location.

Lore: Patrols the Dune Sea searching for lost droids and other items worth scavenging. Armor reinforced to protect against krayt dragon attacks. \b Enclosed\b0.
Gametext: Deploys only on Tatooine. May add 1 driver and 7 passengers. While your Jawa is aboard, this vehicle and your Jawas at same site are immune to attrition < 3. Power +2 if Wittin at same site.
Information: Sandcrawlers are:\par \par Sandcrawler\par Wittin's Sandcrawler\par -----\par Never thought you'd see a unique Sandcrawler, did you? Well, this crawler is the best for hanging out at the Jawa Camp. All you need is one Jawa to stay onboard to get the immunity to attrition. And you know, you're going to have Witten at the Camp. This makes the Sandcrawler a power 5. But if you add Pote Snitkin, it becomes a power 8. Now that's a Sandcrawler. And Pote lets it move for free. Just the thing to traverse the deserts.\par \par This simple transport vehicle becomes a great war machine with which to take control of the Tatooine expanses. And just for an added surprise, initiate a battle against your opponent and then play Heavy Fire Zone. You can then deploy from the Reserve Deck a Dual Laser Cannon(for free). This makes the Sandcrawler a power 11. Plus you have a huge gun, and the Sandcrawler just became immune to attrition < 5.

Lore: Wookiees have been known to dislocate more than just arms.
Gametext: Use 2 Force to target an opponent's non-droid character present with one of your Wookiees. Both players draw destiny. Add ability and power. Target lost if Wookiee's total destiny > target's total destiny.
Information: This interrupt from Cloud City has the potential to give you an advantage in certain situations... That is, if you have a Wookiee around to grab your opponent's non-droid characters by the throat.\par \par For instance, say your opponent has Davin Felth and two Stormtroopers at the Death Star Docking Bay, where you have Chewbacca and Lando Calrissian present. Your opponent's total power is four and ability is four (therefore a battle destiny), while your total power is eight and ability is five (also a battle destiny). Because your opponent draws a battle destiny, chances are that you will have to forfeit either of your characters. However, if Chewbacca Wookiee Strangles a Stormtrooper first, your opponent will not be able to draw battle destiny anymore and since you still do, you will probably be able to cause a lot of battle damage.\par \par Wookiee Strangle is also just good for eliminating annoying characters such as the not-so-good doctor himself, Dr.Evazan, and even your opponent's Undercover Spies! Bye-Bye Garindan and Labria, you should never upset a Wookiee. :)
Combo: Wookiee Strangle + any Chewbacca + Chewbacca's Bowcaster + Sorry About The Mess\par Your opponent has two characters less than he started the turn with - in your control phase.

Lore: Corellian \b gambler\b0  with an addiction to Podrace betting. Has lost most of his belongings to Gardulla. Still operates as a \b smuggler\b0  of black market weaponry.
Gametext: Adds 2 to power of anything he pilots. Once per turn, may take a just drawn race destiny into hand. Once during a battle Yade is in at a system may use 2 Force to draw destiny. If destiny is odd, add one battle destiny; if even, take destiny into hand.

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par Yade may only take your (Dark side's) just-drawn race destiny into hand, not your opponent's.

Lore: "Steady. Hey! Steady, girl. Hey, what's the matter? You smell something?"
Gametext: Target a creature vehicle at same site as a creature. If ferocity > target's maneuver + landspeed, creature vehicle is eaten, \b cumulatively\b0  adding 2 to creature's ferocity.
Information: First, deploy a Wampa, for free, to the Wampa cave. Then put a few Banthas outside (to answer the question I hear every time I do this, no Banthas do NOT deploy only to Tatooine!). During your move phase, the Wampa goes outside to find a few tasty morsels hanging around. Target the first one and draw destiny. As long as you draw a 1, the Bantha is eaten, (Wampa is ferocity 3 + destiny). After that you don't need to worry about missing a draw! Eat a few more, then set the Wampa loose against your opponent!\par \par Hoth offers the Dark Side some great Force drain and fighting locations. Once you have a 9 + destiny ferocity Wampa running loose, you'll find those AT-A's to be wonderful havens and your opponent will be wishing he had a snowspeeder or two to hide in! The Wampa attacks anything present at the same site, so the Light Side undercover spies won't stand a chance, and you can keep draining without hindrance! And if your opponent decides to stand and fight, you can thin his forces before a shot is fired (Remember, creature attacks occur at the beginning of EVERY battle phase). Even if an opponent's character survives a Wampa attack, that character can't participate in any battles that turn.
IsPulled: Tauntaun Skull

Lore: The youngest handmaiden, Yane stayed behind on Naboo while Amidala pleaded her case to the Galactic Senate. \b Musician\b0.
Gametext: While at a Theed Palace site or same site as Amidala, opponent's Republic characters are deploy +1 here and Yane is forfeit +3. If just lost during a battle, may use 2 Force to place Yane in Used Pile.
IsPulled: My Loyal Bodyguard

Lore: Mysterious, secretive aliens. Tend to be found as couriers, \b scouts\b0  and t'bac farmers. Some have helped the Alliance's efforts at counter-espionage.
Gametext: If at same site as an Undercover spy during your control phase, may draw destiny. Each of your Yarkoras on table may cumulatively subtract one from that destiny. Spy's "cover is broken" if destiny = spy's ability.
Information: While many of the other characters from Jabba's are there to create hardship for your opponent, this character is purely offensive. The true counter-espionage agent of your characters, Yarkora can infiltrate and destroy them. Adding a number of them together will only make it easy to crack the Undercover and remove those pesky problems.
IsPulled: General Crix Madine\par Might Of The Republic\par Soth Petikkin (when at a Jabba's Palace site you control)\par Arleil Schous\par Nar Shaddaa Wind Chimes\par Nar Shaddaa Wind Chimes & Out Of Somewhere
Combo: Yarkora + Sorry About the Mess\par Though Yarkora is not a warrior, use Sai'torr Kal Fas or just combine him with another character who can carry a weapon. This will create a team that is sure to beat the spies.

Lore: Female dancer from Askajia. Very protective mother. Makes sure that all those she cares about are well protected.
Gametext: Deploy on your side of the table. While you have fewer than 13 cards in hand, your non-unique cards in hand (except Effects of any kind and Interrupts) are immune to Monnok. (Immune to Alter while you occupy 2 battlegrounds).
Information: This card has one purpose. Protection for a any of the viable non-unique theme decks. The real question is whether to start with it, or try to get it later in the game. Either way, many of the theme decks rely on effects to power them, so including additional copies of The Signal in this deck will probably be rewarded. This allows you to start with Yarna to avoid that first turn Monnok, and deploy your other effects (the Jawa effects for Jawa decks, Haven for a starship deck, Echo Base Operations, etc.) at a time later in the game when you are prepared to capitalize on them.
IsPulled: The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once\par Kashyyyk: Sacred Forest (V)

Lore: Rebel sentries are stationed on raised sensor platforms. On watch for Imperial scouts and other hazards, they supplement data gathered by Yavin Base's main sensors.

Lore: \b Senator\b0  who opposes the taxation of trade routes. Some say that a recent move from his homeworld to a luxurious Coruscant abode is evidence of his corruption.
Gametext: \b Agendas\b0 : trade, wealth. While in a senate majority, once during your turn, may peek at top card of opponent's Reserve Deck; return that card or lose 1 Force to make it lost.
Information: With his trade agenda, he works well with This Is Outrageous! by allowing you to exchange cards you don't need from your hand for (hopefully) better cards in your Lost Pile.\par And with his wealth agenda, he allows you to fully utilize Motion Supported to enhance your battle destinies. But the rest of his game text is what sets him apart from the rest of the senators. Looking at your opponent's destinies would be a very useful ability by itself. It lets you decide whether it would be a good idea to battle since you check whether your opponent's weapon destinies will be dangerous to you, or if you can handle that draw against you for battle destiny.\par But Yeb Yeb goes further by tilting the tides of chance in your favor. If the destiny is low, you can leave it on your opponent's Reserve Deck, but if it's a high destiny you can make it lost and try your luck with the next card.
IsPulled: Squabbling Delegates
Combo: Yeb Yeb Adem'thorn + senate majority + a 6 on opponent's Reserve Deck\par Not any more...\par -----\par Yeb Yeb Adem'thorn + senate majority + only one card in opponent's Reserve Deck\par No destiny for your opponent!\par -----\par Yeb Yeb Adem'thorn + Rune Haako\par Destiny of zero for your opponent. (Lord Helmet)

Lore: An Imperial bureaucrat with high security clearance who resigned and fled in remorse after the occupation of his home planet, Ralltiir. Now a fugitive from the ISB.
Gametext: Deploy at any location. You may move Mig like a character. Target an opponent's character, who may apprehend (cancel) Mig by reaching same location. Until then, during all battles at same and adjacent sites to Mig, opponent's total power is -1.
IsPulled: The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par This Utinni Effect is not a character and may not be targeted as a character. Yerka Mig deploys and moves like a character, but does not require presence or Force icons and does not count toward vehicle or starship capacity. While at a system or sector location, Yerka Mig does not affect the opponent's power.

Lore: Help you I can, yes. For 800 years have I trained Jedi. Judge me by my size do you? Mm? And well you should not! For my ally is the Force... and a powerful ally it is.
Gametext: Deploy on Dagobah I must, but move elsewhere I may, yes. When the mentor, 1 to training destiny I add. Where present am I, battles and attacks happen not unless present a Dark Side character of ability > 3 there is. To attrition, immune am I.
Information: Yoda personas are:\par \par Yoda\par Yoda, Keeper Of The Peace\par Yoda, Master Of The Force\par Yoda, Jedi Council Member\par -----\par This card is one of the two good cards in the Dagobah expansion and the other good card is the Darth Vader flag ship you know what card I'm talking about. And if you don't you don't desevre to play the SW:CCG, ok I'm wrong the only people who don't deserve to play the SW:CCG are evil card stealers. If you are won of them I hope someone steals your hard earned cards that you have collected.\par Lets look at the good points of this card. He has an ability of 7 the highest any character can have and with an ability like that you automaticly draw a battle desinity. Since he is a Jedi Master he makes it so you put an extra force in your force pile. Battles only happen where there is a character with an ability bigger then three which I happen to like. And last of all the good points he's immune to attrition.\par It's bad points time, and this card does have some. Power two, but what did you expect from such a little character. He can only deploy to Dagobah, but you wouldn't he would deploy anywhere else seeing since thats the only place you see him in this trilogy.\par After looking at this card many times I think this is a very good card that would be very good in many types od decks, but remember he can't be used in all light side decks. And you can't just put him in a deck because you think he's cool.
IsPulled: Tatooine: City Outskirts\par Yoda, You Seek Yoda
Combo: Yoda + Encampment\par Deploy regardless of location deployment restrictions.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-16)\par A Dark Side character of ability > 3 is only required to initiate battle (or attack) at Yoda's location. Thus even if that character is later excluded, the battle will continue (assuming other Dark Side presence is still participating).

Lore: "For the Jedi it is time to eat as well."
Gametext: During opponent's turn, take up to four cards from your hand and place them on top of your Force Pile.

Lore: A symbol of the Jedi Master and his ancient wisdom. Speak softly you may but a big stick you must carry, yes.

It does not overcome any other rule or cardbased battle initiation restrictions (such as the requirement of presence, or the restrictive text on Duel Of Fates).

Lore: Kadas'sa'Nikto. \b Smuggler\b0  who stole from shipments going in and out of Jabba's Palace. Part of Jabba's sail barge crew. Not trusted by anyone.
Gametext: Adds 2 to power of anything he pilots. Opponent's combat vehicles are each power -2 at same site. Once per game, may take Mechanical Failure and/or Free Ride into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle.
Information: First point of note is that he is a smuggler. This means an option for your Watch Your Step deck. What's more, he's a pilot, capable of Kessel Running if Dash is on holidays. There are a few other related benefits for smugglers such as cheap deploy to Kashyyyk, or meeting a requirement in your Profit deck so you can play Jabba's Palace sabacc! Beware a Death Mark, though.\par \par His text provides him with a great all-round ability against opponent's vehicular threats. Power -2 against combat vehicles at same site (note that Yotts does not have to be present, so feel free to hide him inside a vehicle of your own!), and a once-per-game grab of Free Ride (steal a vehicle) and/or Mechanical Failure (Lateral Damage a vehicle!). If you are playing either of these cards, Yotts may beg for consideration!
Pulls: Free Ride\par Free Ride & Endor Celebration\par Mechanical Failure
IsPulled: Soth Petikkin (when at a Jabba's Palace site you control).

Lore: "It is useless to resist. Don't let yourself be destroyed as Obi-Wan did."
Gametext: Use 2 Force to target a character present with your warrior with a lightsaber. Target cannot move or battle until end of your next turn. OR Use 1 Force to search your Reserve Deck, take one I Am Your Father into hand and reshuffle. OR Cancel Uncontrollable Fury.
Information: You Are Beaten is one of those multi-use cards that is probably mostly used for only one of it's abilities while the other one is completely forgotten. It is the only card which cancels Uncontrollable Fury (one of the best cards from Cloud City, in my opinion, I won two games in a tournament because of it), but it's other ability can also be a game breaker.\par \par For example...your opponent is draining at the Cantina for two...oh let's say three, you deployed a Presence Of The Force early and lost control of the location...no, make that four, he has Obi deployed there with HIS saber...no, okay five, Luke is there with Anakin's Saber...oh by the way, he played a Lightsaber Proficiency on his last turn...look, Billy, that's a drain for six every control phase!!! You have a Vader and Vader's Saber in your hand, but aren't sure if you can beat Obi, Luke, Han, and Kal'Fnal Cndros (yep he's there too) with Vader, Ozzel, and Veers (by the way, they're in your hand too). Oh my goodness, you have a YOU ARE BEATEN in your hand!!!\par \par Things are looking MUCH better, you have a lot of Force to use, so you deploy Vader, his Saber, Ozzel, and Veers, then activate that one more that commits you to do battle with your nemeses. Oh wait...what are those other Force there for? YOU ARE BEATEN!!!!! Target OBI, oh, my dear, what's that? Obi CAN'T PARTICIPATE IN THE BATTLE OR MOVE until the end of your NEXT turn. It helps a little, don't ya see? Oh and the other use, if you're playing with I AM YOUR FATHER in your deck, is to go through and grab it after you beat down Luke's happy butt and cause your opponent to lose two MORE Force every turn and Luke won't stand much of a chance against Vader anymore.
Pulls: I Am Your Father
Cancels: Uncontrollable Fury
IsCanceledBy: Impressive, Most Impressive (V)\par Strike Blocked\par Twilight Is Upon Me (unless canceling Uncontrollable Fury)\par Weapon Levitation

CardName: You Have Failed Me For The Last Time
Lore: "Lord Vader, the fleet has moved out of lightspeed and we're preparing to aah...ukh...uh...uuuuukkk!"
Gametext: If Vader is on table when opponent has just initiated a battle, target one opponent's leader of ability < 6 involved in that battle. If opponent does not win battle, target is forfeit = 0 and is lost (placed out of play if Ozzel).

Lore: Echo Base was no match for the Imperial war machine.
Gametext: Deploy on table if 5th marker also on table. During your control phase, opponent loses 1 Force for each marker site you occupy with an AT-AT. Once per game, may take both Walker Garrison and 3rd Marker into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Prepared Defenses.\par -----\par This card heralds the return of the almighty Walker Garrison deck. Being able to start this effect with Prepared Defenses is a great boost to this classic deck type. On your first turn, you can immediately go and grab the 3rd Marker, which combined with the 5th Marker gives you 4 red icons and a +1 Force Drain location, while the Light Side only gets one blue icon from you in the bargain. Plus, you are guaranteed to have a Walker Garrison in hand right from the get-go, so you are all set to drain like mad once you've got all your Walkers in position.\par \par The best part of this card, however, is its ability to deal direct damage just by occupying Hoth marker sites with AT-ATs, which any self-respecting Walker Garrison deck has in abundance. If you choose No Escape as one of your starting effects, this direct damage will not be cancelled by Honor of the Jedi, which is a good thing since your force drains at non-battlegrounds will be negated by that powerful Light Side card. Be sure to pack a couple Presence of the Force to help turn those Marker Sites into battlegrounds and add to your drains in the bargain.\par \par For a third starting effect for this deck type, you probably want to start with Imperial Arrest Order. This will give a big boost to all your Walker pilots, and allow you to deploy the Hoth: Echo Docking Bay right away, a great place to plop a Walker to help drain with Walker Garrison. Unfortunately, the Docking Bay isn't a Marker Site, but it's still a great battleground to drain at with your Walkers. An alternative starting effect is Imperial Decree, which is pretty easy to keep active with this deck and which can really hurt those cowardly Rebels.
Pulls: Hoth: Defensive Perimeter\par Walker Garrison\par Walker Garrison (V)
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-17)\par "Occupy with an AT-AT" means that you must occupy the location, and the AT-AT cannot be unpiloted.

Gametext: *\b Deploy\b0  on table. *\b Target\b0  a Skywalker who has completed Jedi Test # 5. While target on Dagobah, "move phase" on Save You It Can may be treated as "deploy phase". Until Jedi Test completed, battles you initiate at Vader's site are canceled and opponent loses 2 Force at start of your turn unless Vader is at a battleground site. *\b Attempt\b0  during your move phase when Vader with target (even as a non-frozen captive). Vader and target duel: Each player draws destiny. Add ability. Highest total wins. If target wins, test completed: *\b Leave\b0  on table. Add one battle destiny in every battle. Also, target is immune to attrition < 5.
IsPulled: Dagobah: Training Area
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-17)\par Unlike the other Jedi Tests, this one does not require its target to be on Dagobah. Note that the destiny draw required when attempting the test is part of a duel, and thus is not "training destiny" (it is not subject to training destiny modifiers).

Lore: "Evacuate? In our moment of triumph?"

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-17)\par See Don't Underestimate Our Chances.\par \par (AR 1.7.1, B-6)\par Don't Underestimate Our Chances\par This Interrupt does not triple attrition.
IsCanceledBy: He Can Go About His Business - Defensive Shield\par He Can Go About His Business (V) - Defensive Shield

CardName: You'll Find I'm Full Of Surprises
Lore: Even though he wasn't fully prepared to face the Dark Lord of the Sith, Luke rushed to save his friends.
Gametext: If Luke and Vader present at same site, use 1 Force to initiate a duel between them. Either is power +2 if armed with a lightsaber. Draw destiny. Opponent draws two destiny. Both players add power. Loser is placed out of play.
Information: At first glance, you might say, "Hey, why would I play this card?" After all, although it gives the Light Side a chance to duel, it automatically starts you at a disadvantage, giving the Dark Side two destiny to your one. And although having Luke placed out of play might seem appealing versus a Bring Him Before Me deck, you can't play this card when that Objective is out (due to the Objective's card text).\par \par So what's the point? Well, if you're willing to devote a few extra cards to your Mains deck, this card can certainly be an unwelcome surprise for the Dark Side. Most decks carry a Vader or three, so devoting a bit of your strategy to this card can usually be effective. And it is a 6 Destiny card, so it will always have that bit of usefulness. Now, play two or three of these cards in your deck, and you've got some of the high destiny you need to succeed with this card.\par \par Also, pack Courage of Skywalker to give you another destiny to even things out a bit with the old Dark Lord. And let's not forget Glancing Blow, which allows you to cancel one of the Dark Side's duelling destiny draws or, if you play You'll Find I'm Full of Surprises during the weapons segment of a battle, you can use Glancing Blow to nail Vader's power, knocking it to an unmodifiable zero, which means he won't even get the +2 power from holding his lightsaber granted by the Interrupt. Suddenly, Vader's chances of winning have become quite slim, and it looks like he's going away for a very long time.\par \par Having this sort of a side strategy not only lets you beat up Luke's favorite sparring partner, but also gives you a plethora of cards to defend yourself during duels initiated by the Dark Side with such cards as Epic Duel or new cards like Darth Maul.\par \par Some new Tatooine cards that can help you win the day versus Vader include A Jedi's Focus: which lets you add the destiny of the top card of the Lost Pile to your total, A Jedi's Patience: which lets you redraw one of your bad duelling destiny draws, and most importantly, A Jedi's Resilience, which allows you to cancel a duel AFTER you've lost it AND take the duelling card back into your hand!\par \par But watch out for the new Dark Side card, Lightsaber Parry, or your duel might suddenly become very expensive!

Yoxgit, while not affecting the unfortunate zero drawn for the Overload, can help you get those Lightsabers back into hand, as well as an Electrobinoculars, or any other useful weapon or device. As a character, he is relatively weak for a 2 deploy cost, except on Cloud City. If you have a Light side Cloud City Scenario deck, this character is possibly your best bet for a quick, cheap, powerhouse.

Rules: Draw X Choose Y\par When a card instructs you to draw x destiny and choose y, perform the following steps:\par Step 1) Draw a destiny. This draw can be modified, canceled, reset, or otherwise responded to normally just after it is drawn; however, after being drawn, unless canceled, it remains an Unresolved Destiny Draw and is not yet placed in Used Pile. The draw is considered a weapon destiny, battle destiny, etc. where appropriate, and counts against any applicable limits. If a limit prevents a player from drawing more than x destinies, they instead draw a number of destinies equal to the limit. Repeat this step until x destinies have been drawn. \par Step 2) Once x destines have been drawn, choose a destiny from among the Unresolved Destiny Draws and resolve it normally. Repeat this step until an appropriate number of destinies have been chosen as specified by y. \par Step 3) Place any remaining unresolved draws in used pile (unless otherwise instructed) in the order they were drawn (if possible).\par \par \par Note that this means any just action responding to a just drawn destiny in a Draw X Choose Y situation must do so when it is DRAWN (in step 1) and not when it is CHOSEN (in step 2). Once the process has moved on to Step 2, with the player who drew choosing which destinies to use, the draws can no longer be responded to as just drawn. \par \par Also worth noting is that all destinies drawn with a Draw X Choose Y card count against applicable limits or other cards that count the number of destinies, even if they are not chosen. That is to say, limits count the number of destinies drawn, not the number of destinies chosen. To illustrate, here are a few examples: \par \par Example 1: Dash In Rogue 12 (applicable text: During battle, if with another T-47 and about to draw a battle destiny, may draw two and choose one.) is in a battle with another T-47, and the Light Side player is limited to ONE battle destiny. In this situation Dash In Rogue 12's 'draw 2 and choose 1' text cannot be used because both destinies drawn with Dash count as battle destiny draws. \par \par Example 2: If a similar situation played out, but the Light Side player was limited 2 battle destinies instead of 1, the Light Side player using Dash In Rogue 12's text on 1 destiny would reach the limit of two battle destinies on its own, because even though only one such destiny would be chosen, two destinies were still drawn. If the light side player had a way to add a battle destiny in this example, they would be better off NOT using Dash In Rogue 12's text and simply drawing 2 normal destinies, because using Dash In Rogue 12's text on the first destiny would cause them to reach the limit of 2, preventing them from drawing the added battle destiny after. \par \par Example 3: Dash In Rogue 12 is in a battle with Commander Luke Skywalker v piloting Rogue 1 (so that Luke draws 2 battle destiny if unable to otherwise). Luke's text will be usable because when it checks how many destinies Light Side is scheduled to draw at the beginning of the power segment, it will only see 1. (Luke's text only counts one destiny able to be drawn because Dash In Rogue 12's text has not triggered yet - it is only usable when the Light Side is about to draw a battle destiny) While the Light Side may theoretically use Dash In Rogue 12's text to draw 2 and choose 1 on the first destiny drawn, they would no longer be able to draw the 2nd destiny with Luke's text, because players may never combine multiple destiny drawing to draw more than the 'if unable to otherwise' text allows (see "Battle Destiny - Draws X Battle Destiny If Unable To Otherwise" on AR page 6-6). In this case, drawing 2 and choosing 1 on the first destiny and attempting to draw the second would mean the Light Side would be drawing 3 battle destinies, which would be prevented by 'if unable to otherwise' rules. If the first destiny with Luke's text is drawn normally, the Light Side player may not use Dash In Rogue 12's text on the second destiny from Luke's text, because again, that would result in the Light Side player drawing 3 destinies and would be prevented. In short, like example 2, the Light Side player would be better off simply drawing 2 normal battle destinies rather than using Dash In Rogue 12's text in this situation.
